talk.start.para: - Does the Leader of the Government in the Senate know that a special significance attaches to the date, 2nd September of this year? Does he realize that it has a special significance for himself? Does he know that on that date he established a new parliamentary record? Does he know that on that date he achieved the distinction of serving the longest continuous term in the Senate as Leader of the Government? Does he realize that he eclipsed the previous record of Sir George Pearce, who held that office from February, 1923, to October, 1929, a total of six years eight months and fourteen days? Will the Leader of the Government accept the personal congratulations of the members of the Opposition upon achieving a record? Does he realize that, speaking now from a party view-point, the only consolation that the Opposition derives from a contemplation of the record is the fact that the end of the life of the Government is nearer by six years, eight months and sixteen days?

- I think the Leader of the Opposition should have given notice of that question. It is not very often that he rises to ask a question; few honorable senators ask fewer questions than he does. But, whenever he has risen in the past to ask a question, I have always felt, no matter how courteous he has been - he is always very courteous - that his question was not designed to give me either comfort or pleasure. However, in his question this afternoon, I detect a note of cordiality and goodwill which affords me great pleasure and great comfort. I do not know how the Leader of the Opposition finds time to delve as closely as apparently he does into the minute details of history. Some time last year I had occasion to look at the periods of office of various holders of positions in the Senate. Although I cannot be so precise as to give the number of days, I am inclined to agree that the Leader of the Opposition is right. Senator Pearce held the position of Leader of the Government in the Senate for three or four periods, aggregating about thirteen years. Senator Millen held that position, I think, for three periods aggregating about eight years. It has been a great pleasure to me to occupy the position and to hold it continuously for a record period. During that period, we have had many ups and downs and many fights, but permeating our relations there has been, I think, a feeling of mutual goodwill. Our debates have been remarkably and pleasantly free from personal recriminations and personal bitterness. The game has been played hard on occasions, and I hope that it will continue to be played hard, but I trust that we shall continue to play the ball, or the argument, rather than the personality or the man. I appreciate very much the sentiments inherent in the question asked by the Leader of the Opposition. I cannot offer him any hope that the leadership of the Senate will leave our hands in the foreseeable future. I do not know how long I personally shall hold that office, because that is a matter that will be determined by my leader, the Prime Minister. I hope that if and when I vacate the office it will, pass to one of my colleagues. I say again that I appreciate the very cordial sentiments in the question asked by Senator McKenna.

- by leave - I extend to the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator O'Sullivan) congratulations from, I hope, both sides of the Senate, on establishing what I think may fairly be called a minor historic record in the records of the Senate. Speaking now on behalf of this side of the chamber only, I want to say that we appreciate very much indeed the action of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) in putting his question so nicely and with such obvious good spirit. This is one of those little occasions that make political life more bearable and a little more pleasant. If my colleagues behind me will permit me to do so, I should like to pay a tribute to the Leader of the Government in the Senate from his colleagues in the Ministry. The original team has been reduced by two. The absence of those two members is a matter of regret to us all. I would like to say to the Senate, and to >Senator O'Sullivan in particular, that I know of no happier family than the family of Ministers in the Senate, lt is commonly said around the Cabinet table, "If you hit one Senator Minister, you hit the lot". That is the atmosphere in which we have worked because of the pleasant personality of the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and the encouragement he has given us. I assure the Leader of the Government, on behalf of Government senators and. I believe, on behalf of the Opposition, that he has made an excellent contribution to the dignity and prestige of the Senate by his unfailing courtesy, consideration, kindliness and friendliness to all of us. I congratulate him upon establishing a record in his term of office, and upon the way in which he has carried out his duties.

- I preface a question to the Minister representing the Minister for the Army by saying that it was reported in the Australian press yesterday that Australia had troops of a battalion strength ready for immediate action overseas if required. Reports in the press to-day state that Egyptian sources have conveyed the impression that an Australian battalion was available for immediate action if negotiations on the Suez Canal broke down. Will the Minister state whether such a statement was made and, if so, what was the statement and who made it?
-I discussed this matter with the Minister for the Army who has informed me, without any reservation at ali, that no such statement was made by him.

- By way of preface to a question to the Minister representing the Treasurer, I wish to state that, since the Senate met last, the large reclaimed area on the lower Murray in South Australia known as Jervois has been lost to floods. Many offers of agistment for the 7,000 dairy cows thus displaced have come from farmers and graziers in the Adelaide hills and throughout the south-east of South Australia, but unless the necessary dairy installations and accommodation for those who tend these dairy cows are provided, the eventual dispersal of those herds is almost inescapable. That would bo a serious blow to the Adelaide domestic milk supply. Will the Minister discuss urgently with the Treasurer the possibility of allowing, in the year of expenditure, income tax deductions to land-holders who erect dairy structures and provide accommodation on land made available for the agistment of such dairy cattle? I point out thai during the second world war, depreciation allowances were granted with respect to plant and buildings used and constructed in consequence of emergency war-time conditions.

- I remind the honorable senator that the Government has already informed the South Australian Government that it is prepared to contribute on a ?l-for-?l basis for the relief of cases of hardship resulting from the floods. It has also informed the South Australian Government that it would be prepared to contribute towards the rehabilitation of roads. &c, provided the South Australian Government submitted the case properly. If I understood the honorable senator's question correctly, he is suggesting assistance in a third category to cover the replacement or construction of buildings for dairy herds that may be dispersed. As the honorable senator's question was asked without notice, I can only give him an assurance that I shall take the matter up with the Treasurer and ascertain his views about it.

- By way of preface to my question, which is directed to the Minister for the Navy, may I state that there is grave concern among employees of the naval dockyards at Garden Island, New South Wales, and Williamstown, Victoria, following the receipt by many of them of notices of dismissal. Will the Minister give consideration to the withdrawal of these notices in view of the gravity of the international situation, which makes the dispersal of skilled dockyard staffs at the present time undesirable from a defence and security viewpoint, and the possibility that staffs may be kept at full strength by permitting the dockyards to accept private shipbuilding orders and general repair work?

- The prospect of unemployment is not pleasing to anybody, whether he be a member of the Government parties or the Opposition; but it should be borne in mind that from all quarters, including quarters represented by Senator Cole, the Opposition and the Government parties, there have been demands for the reduction of defence expenditure. If less money is spent, then there must be less employment. However, I assure the honorable senator that the money available for expenditure by the Department of the Navy will be spent in a way that will preserve the maximum of employment and ensure that the incidence of unemployment shall be as small as possible.
- What is the possibility of the dockyards engaging in private shipbuilding work?
- Any such work will have to be paid for.

- Has the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Territories been directed to a report from Port Moresby that Public Works Department carpenters are building special accommodation for a woman at the Bomana gaol? Has an appeal been lodged on behalf of this person, and if so has bail been refused? If no appeal is pending and the Bomana gaol has accommodation only for native prisoners and for a few male Europeans, will the Minister please explain why the prisoner was not moved to the mainland for detention?

- I cannot answer the honorable senator's question immediately, but I assure her that I shall get in touch with the Minister for Territories and have the whole matter investigated and a reply furnished to the honorable senator as soon as possible.

- My question is directed to the Minister for National Development. In view of the continued dismissals of miners on the northern coalfields, will the Minister make a statement about the prospects of employment in the coalmining industry, with particular reference to the northern coalfields?

- I doubt the need for a statement on employment in the coalmining industry. The latest figures that I have show that the total number of employees in the coalmining industry at. 25th August, 1956, was 18,154, which is only about 340 less than the number employed at the end of December. 1955. Coal consumption has fallen somewhat, but the production from underground mines for the 27 weeks to the month of August was only 110,000 tons less than for the corresponding period of last year. That quantity of 110,000 tons has to be measured in relation to the production of 7,369,000 tons. The re-arrangements occurring on the coal-fields are, at least up to this stage, due rather to more efficient production at the mines as a result of their greater mechanization, than to a declining demand for coal. I do not think that I can elaborate that to any great extent. The great trouble in the coal-mining industry has been its lack of mechanization, and ?3.000.000 or ?4,000,000 a year is being spent by colliery proprietors to achieve more efficient production. Greater mechanization, of course, results in a lower number of employees, but the Government is watching the position from week to week. A committee is concentrating on this matter, and as men are cavilled out at mines, every care is taken to offer them employment opportunities elsewhere. I receive figures each week, and I am citing some of them to-day. The latest I have before me are dated the 30th August, and show that only one person was registered for unemployment relief on the whole of the four coal-field areas in New South Wales at that date, but there were sixteen registered for positions in mines. I admit to the honorable senator that that was a most favorable week. I should not like honorable senators to think that it was a normal period. However, this statement illustrates how closely we are keeping in touch with the position and that we are doing all that we can to avoid unnecessary hardship during a process which, obviously, is for the long-term good of the industry. The more the industry is brought up to date and made efficient, the greater is the possibility of increasing the market for coal and of expanding the industry. While these improvements are being made, however, there must be adjustments in employment at the various mines.

- I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Health, and preface it by pointing out that in the United States of America a new anti-polio vaccine is being manufactured under the name of Sabin, which certain medical authorities consider may prove to have more lasting immunizing qualities than the present vaccine Salk. Will the Minister have this report investigated, and if necessary, send an appropriate medical officer overseas to investigate Sabin vaccine?

- I can say, on behalf of the Minister for Health, that Salk vaccine, which has been manufactured and used in Australia for some months, has had very considerable success. I assure the honorable senator that I will bring to the notice of the Minister for Health his statement concerning the new vaccine he has mentioned. I shall ask, the Minister to furnish a report on what Sabin vaccine is and whether it is proving more successful than Salk vaccine.

- I direct a question to the Leader of the Government concerning press statements to the effect that troops are being prepared to go overseas, if necessary, in connexion with the Suez Canal dispute. The Government denies having authorized these reports, and I accept its denial, but has the Leader of the Government made any effort to ascertain who isresponsible for making them? Will the Minister take the necessary action to prevent the publication of such statements, particularly if they are without foundation, because they could be regarded as a direct act of sabotage against the Prime Minister who is at present engaged on a very difficult mission, and could also damage Australia'sgood name and friendly relations with other countries?

- The making of inquiries as suggested by the honorable senator would be a matter for the acting, head of the Government rather than for me as Leader of the Senate. I have no doubt that Sir Arthur Fadden has already madeinvestigations into the false report mentioned by the honorable senator.

- My questions are directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Civil Aviation. Following the suspension of a pilot, Captain James Wood, of Woods Airways, Perth, from flying between Perth and Rottnest Island, because of a stated unsafe landing strip, can the Minister for Civil Aviation inform the Senate what measures are necessary to ensure safety for passengers landing on and leaving this island strip? When will the necessary alterations be made? What will be the approximate cost of such alterations?

- The incident to which the honorable senator has referred in her question has caused considerable public interest in Western Australia. I shall get a full statement from my colleague, the Minister for Civil Aviation, and let the honorable senator have it.

- Will the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry cause to be investigated reports to the effect that potatoes are being cornered in Sydney, Melbourne and Brisbane by middlemen, profiteers and racketeers? Will he also investigate the report that potatoes are being cornered in Melbourne in order that they can be released at an excess, price in that city during the Olympic Games?

- I am, of course, aware of the importance of the question in that there is a shortage of potatoes in the cities mentioned and that prices have been exorbitant. I am not too sure whether this is a matter for the Minister for Primary Industry whom I represent. There are many aspects of it, some of them of a purely marketing nature, which might more appropriately be a subject for investigation in the States and cities concerned. However, I shall consult with my colleague, the Minister for Primary Industry, and ascertain if there is anything he can say which might throw a little light on the situation.

- My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Labour and National Service. It has reference to the Committee of Inquiry into the Stevedoring Industry which was constituted under the chairmanship of Mr. J. B. Tait in November, 1954. It will be remembered that the two other members who sat on that committee with the chairman were Mr. J. Shortell and Mr. F. J. R. Gibson. I ask the Minister whether the report is correct that those two men have been appointed to the new stevedoring industry authority. If so, was the report, the task of the committee, completed at the date of the appointments of these two men? If not, is it expected that those two gentlemen will participate in the completion of the report?
- It is correct that those two gentlemen have been appointed to the commission. I am sorry that I cannot answer the honorable senator's other questions. I ask that they be put on notice.

- I ask the Minister representing the Minister for External Affairs the following questions: - Is it a fact that Russia, last year, made an offer to Egypt to finance the building of the Aswan high dam project? Did the United States of America and Great Britain make arrangements to lend money to Egypt for the same purpose? Was the latter offer withdrawn, and, if so, why? I do not think the Minister will be able to answer my last question. If the offer were withdrawn, did that fact influence or force Egypt to nationalize the Suez Canal in order to raise funds for building the dam?

- The questions raised by the honorable senator are certainly of great international interest, but not one of the four questions asked by him comes within the jurisdiction of this Parliament. Therefore, I am not in a position to give him a factual answer to them, great as the interest inherent in them may be.

- My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Social Services. Is he aware of the great hardship being experienced by age pensioners and their wives in cases when the wives have not reached the pensionable age, so that both are forced to exist on a pension that is not really adequate for one? Will the Minister consider granting a pension to the wife of an age pensioner when the wife is over 50 years of age as it is both impracticable and undesirable for her to obtain employment at that age?

- The age at which pensions should become payable has been considered from time to time by governments of different political colours. The present formula provides that a female becomes eligible for a pension at an age five years younger than the age at which a male becomes eligible. I think it is the general opinion that that is a reasonable arrangement, and it is one which this Government believes should be continued.
asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, upon notice -

item.para: Has the Minister seen the figures supplied by the Commonwealth Statistician in relation to the disparity between the numbers of Italians and British nationals entering this country?
Is it a fact that, in the quarter ended the 31st March, the net increase of Italian nationals was 9,460 compared with a net increase 7,119 British nationals?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Immigration has furnished the following reply: -

item.para: Yes.

It is most misleading to accept the published figures at their face value and it is of the greatest importance that these figures should be correctly interpreted. Failure to realize this has led to many misconceptions in the past. The term "permanent arrivals" as used by the Commonwealth Statistician includes all those people coming to Australia for the first time and those Australians who have been abroad for a year or longer who intend to remain in Australia for twelve months or more, irrespective of their eventual intentions. Similarly, " permanent departures " cover, in addition to those persons who do not intend returning to Australia, all persons who have been in Australia for twelve months or more and who are leaving Australia with the intention of being away twelve months or more. The number of Australians departing for periods of twelve months or more in any one quarter, for a variety of reasons, does not necessarily balance the number shown as returning in the same period. In the actual period under consideration Australians departing for twelve months or more exceeded Australians returning after absences of twelve months or more by more than 2 1/2 to 1. The result was obviously an artificially low British net migration figure. Thus figures provided by the Commonwealth Statistician for the March quarter show that British permanent arrivals numbered 15,932 and Italian permanent arrivals 10,048.

answer.para: Permanent departures " during the quarter were 8,813 in the case of British and S88 in the case of Italians, leaving a rather spurious " net permanent migration" figure of 7,119 British and 9,460 Italians. Since the great majority of Australian residents leaving for trips abroad would be British subjects, it is clear that the figures for British " permanent departures ", according to the Commonwealth Statistician's definition, under ordinary circumstances, would be much higher than the figure for " permanent departures " of other nationalities. I have already mentioned that during the January-March, 1956, quarter the Italian permanent departures figure was 588 as opposed to the nominal British permanent departures figure of 8,813. However, of the 8,813 British so-called " permanent departures " during the period, Australian residents going abroad for more than twelve months numbered 5,857 while temporary visitors to Australia departing after visits of more than twelve months numbered 940. The balance, 2,016, would be the " real " British permanent departure figure, and this number would include - (a) permanent departures to Papua and New Guinea which are akin to movements from one part of Australia to another; (b) permanent departures to New Zealand; (c) Australian-born citizens going abroad; and (d) a small number only of pre- and post-war migrants. By taking the above points into consideration a much more favorable picture is revealed of the net proportion of British to Italian migrants in the January-March figure. In essence the position is that the British net permanent migration figure is deflated by the large numbers of Australians going abroad for more than twelve months, while the net permanent migration figures for other nationalities, including Italians, are obviously not so deflated. Recently, as the honorable senator will be aware, certain alterations were made in the categories of southern Europeans, including Italians, eligible for migration, the result of which will be a reduction in the numbers coming forward from this area in the future. Figures released by the United Kingdom Board of Trade show that in the post-war period until June, 1955 (the latest date for which such figures are available) total migration to Australia from the United Kingdom has been only slightly below the combined total going to the three other main British-receiving countries - Canada, South Africa and New Zealand. For the latest available period, the six months ended June, 1955, these figures indicate that Australia received 48.1 per cent, of such movement compared with -

These figures speak for themselves, particularly having regard to the fact that, in common with New Zealand, Australia is at a disadvantage compared with the other countries because of its greater distance from the United Kingdom. Australia is taking as many migrants from the United Kingdom as possible at the present time and numbers are limited only by availability of suitable accommodation. By far the greater percentage of migrants from the United Kingdom have gone to accommodation provided by friends and relatives under personal nomination arrangements. It is the Government's policy to encourage migration from the United Kingdom in the greatest possible numbers, lt more Australian residents could be induced to nominate persons living in the United Kingdom, it follows that it would be possible numbers. If more Australian residents The essential factor in such nominations is, oi course, the provision of accommodation. In addition as many families as possible are brought out under the Commonwealth Nomination Scheme, in which case accommodation is provided under government arrangements in the first instance. However, the number of such migrants is limited by the availability of hostel accommodation. The position is, therefore, that whilst the policy of the Government is to ensure the maximum British intake within the overall immigrat ion programme this intake is to a large extent governed by the availability of accomm odation both private and government arranged, which can be provided for them. At the present time the Government is taking full advantage of the high rate of applications for migration to Australia from the United Kingdom by using all suitable shipping and accommodation available. Every available berth on commercial shipping lines serving Australia from the United Kingdom is at present fully booked for British migrants. In addition, the "New Australia ", which we own with the British Government, is being used exclusively for the transport of migrants from the United Kingdom. We have, moreover, recently experimented with chartered foreign shipping in order to increase our British intake. As further evidence of the Government's desire to do all in its power to attract and assist migrants from the United Kingdom, I should mention that we pay about 85 per cent, of the fare of each assisted migrant from the United Kingdom compared with 21 per cent, of the fares of assisted migrants from other areas. Finally, it is of interest to note that of the 1,031,308 permanent arrivals Australia has received between October, 194S, and December, 1955, 496,614 ur 48.2 per cent, were of British nationality, a clear indication of the Government's determination to foster and maintain the predominantly British character of the Australian population.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Production, upon notice -

item.para: Will the Minister advise the Senate whether the heavy equipment used on the St. Mary's project is owned by Utah Construction (Australia) or is rented? If rented, will the Minister advise from whom, and on what terms and conditions?
ls the cost of procuring spare parts for the heavy equipment paid for by the Government, or by the owners or lessees?

Are the Government vehicles at this project used exclusively for purposes of the project or are they used for any other purposes? If used for other purposes, how is the purchase price and maintenance cost of such vehicles allocated?
Is the physical work on the St. Mary's project in advance of the architect's plans; if so, for what reason?
Is the firm of A. C. Hyistendahl and Associates still connected with the project? If not, for what reason did they cease their connexion?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Defence Production has supplied the following answers: -

item.para: Most of the equipment is owned by Utah Australia Limited. Most recent figures available disclose that 26 items of equipment were on rental from outside parties compared with 57 from Utah. The existing " Job Instructions " provide that Utah (Australia) Limited will endeavour to secure equipment at the lowest possible price in accordance with the spirit and letter of agreed purchasing procedures. Rental rates and conditions are subject to approval by the Central Control Agency. In addition to Utah, the following parties are supplying equipment: - Thiess Brothers Proprietary Limite.1, George-street, Sydney; Tutt Bryant Proprietary Limited, South-street, Rydalmere; Cleary Brothers, Kiama; Agriplan Proprietary Limited, Pitt-street, Sydney; Braybon Brothers Proprietary Limite.1, Washington-street, Sydney; Neuchate Asphalt Company, George-street, Sydney; Bitu-' minous Pavements Proprietary Limited, Prospect: S. Hassaratti, Roseberry-road, Killara: M. Posner. Clark-street, Berala: A. Brien, High-street, Strathfield; E. W. Fitzgerald, Stuart-street, Burwood.

The contractor purchases the spare parts on behalf of the Commonwealth at job cost. One of the conditions of hire of plant is that the cost of major overhauls will be borne by the hirers. All overhauls are done in the project workshops and the cost of major overhauls, including parts, is recovered from the hirers. Normal maintenance is a job cost.

The government vehicles on the joh are provided for exclusive use on the project. The use of vehicles is controlled by "Job Instructions" which provide that " no personal use of automobiles or overnight use of automobiles will be permitted except with the expressed prior approval of the Central Control Agency ". No approvals have been granted for the private use of vehicles. The "Job Instructions " provide a schedule of rates to be charged if the private use of automobiles is approved. These rates are the same as those approved by the Public Service Board for cases where officers of the Public Service use their own cars on departmental business.
The architect who is controlling this project advises that the answer is " No ".

A. C. Hyistendahl and Associates were employed by the architects for the project as a control and expediting agency. Their association with the project ceased at 31st May, 1956. They were employed by the architect, not by the Government.

debate.para: Debate resumed from 22nd May (vide page 851), on motion by Senator Arnold -

quote.para: That the report be printed.

talk.start.para: . - The motion before the Senate deals with the tenth report of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. It was directed at achieving a particular purpose. That purpose has been accomplished, but the mere fact that that is so would not justify passing by this report. That is true for two reasons. In the first place, the committee should be congratulated upon the work it has done and the report it has submitted. It has shown very great care, has displayed great industry, and has presented one of the most complete and succinct reports of the kind that I have ever read. Attached to it are notes of evidence and documents with which the committee was concerned.

speech.para: However, I think there is another reason why I should have something to say in this chamber on the exercise of the power of delegated legislation. After all is said and done, that is an enormous power and, as I see the position, there is a responsibility upon every individual member of this Parliament to satisfy himself that that power is not abused. It is capable of very great abuse, and I acknowledge the personal responsibility that rests on me in the matter. My great consolation and relief is that there is such a body as the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances set up by the Senate, and that it is the duty of that committee to examine the mass of regulations and ordinances that are passed from time to time, and of which the Senate receives notification. It is rather surprising that the Senate alone should have established such a body. No other body in the Parliament is responsible for that particular work. I should have thought that that might well have been the work of a joint committee of the two Houses.

Having regard to the very good work that this committee does, I am rather loath to suggest that an alteration should be made, but perhaps I may be permitted to suggest that it is surprising that the House of Representatives has no comparable body charged with a similar duty. It may be that representatives of that chamber, like myself, are content to leave the matter to the Senate committee. The procedure of that committee, as I understand it, is that, with each regulation and ordinance, there is circulated a memorandum from the relevant department explaining the purpose of the regulation. That is then submitted to an independent private legal advisor to the committee, who is retained and paid from government funds. Then the committee itself addresses its mind to a consideration of the regulation and the reports before it.

The functions of the committee are detailed on the first page of its report, which is now before the Senate. It is pointed out that since 1932, the practice of the committee has been to address itself to four main aspects. They are worth repeating. It scrutinizes regulations and ordinances to ascertain, first, that they are in accordance with the statute that authorizes their making; second, that they do not trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties; third, that they do not make the rights and liberties of citizens unduly dependent on administrative rather than judicial decision; and, finally, that they are concerned with administrative detail and do not amount to substantive legislation that should be a matter for parliamentary enactment.

I should like to say a few words on the subject-matter of the report itself. The report became necessary in relation to Statutory Rule No. 92 of 1955. The detailed regulation is No. 515. The broad effect of the regulation was to provide that, if the Commonwealth suffered loss or damage or expense or there was a deficiency in stores or material in the Royal Australian

Air Force, and the Air Board considered that the loss or damage was attributable to a fault on the part of one of the members of the Royal Australian Air Force, the member should be liable to pay to the Commonwealth the amount of damage as determined by the Air Board, or such amount as the Air Board considered fit. That power of the Air Board Was delegated, in turn, to an officer of the board and his decision, when made, was reviewable by either a senior officer or by the Air Board itself. That was the beginning and the end of the matter.

The Regulations and Ordinances Committee, reviewing that particular regulation purporting to be made under the Air Force Act, had this to say in paragraph 4. of the report that is now before the Senate -

quote.para: Having considered the regulation, the committee is of the opinion -

item.para: that the regulation is not authorized by the Act.

speech.para: That, of course, is a fundamental defect, an?l enough to bring the regulation down, not only in the Parliament but in a court of law. That first finding of the committee is a clear indication of the need for the existence of a body such as this. The second finding in paragraph 4 was - that the Regulation includes provisions for substantial alterations of the law appropriate only to enactment (if at all) by Parliament.-

It is a substantive matter, not an incidental or ancillary matter and, according to the proposition covered by the regulation, should have been dealt with substantively by the Parliament. The third finding of the committee has a number of sub-headings, and it states -

quote.para: That the Regulation authorizes deductions from a member's pay -

item.label: (a)
item.para: not only for deficiency of stores and materials but also for third party claims.

speech.para: If, through the action of an officer of the Royal Australian Air Force, a third party suffered injury, damage or loss and proceeded to claim against the Commonwealth - which he might do and it could be a claim for expensive damages - then the regulation purports to enable that amount to be mulcted from the offending Royal Australian Air Force member. The regulation also authorizes deductions from a member's pay -

item.label: (b)
item.para: of unlimited amounts,

item.label: (c)
item.para: without appeal,

item.label: (d)
item.para: without providing the member with any procedure (such as court martial or civil court action) to be heard, and

item.label: (e)
item.para: without protecting any proportion of the member's periodical pay.

speech.para: Then there is an extraordinary comment - "Notwithstanding that the Air Force Act specifically indicates that section 58 of the Defence Act is to continue to apply to the Air Force." The significance of that comment is that section 58 of the Defence Act therein incorporated in the Air Force Act provides that if any such situation arises involving loss or damage of the nature I have indicated, the commanding officer may recover such loss from the responsible member or officer only by action in a court of law. Despite the fact that that provision was deemed to be incorporated in the Air Force Act, regulation 515 managed to get by the Executive Council. The chairman of the committee that we are discussing very properly moved in this Senate that the regulation be disallowed. That motion was not proceeded with for the very good reason that the Government, having before it the result of the investigations of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, very properly cancelled and withdrew the regulation. So, in that particular instance, the committee completely achieved its purpose.

I believe that the report of the committee serves a wider purpose of directing attention to the need on the part of Ministers, and in particular on the part of the departments behind them, to advert to the principles that have been broken, as this committee has shown so clearly. I congratulate the committee upon its work, and I am grateful to the Senate for establishing such a body and to the committee itself for the work that it has done. As Leader of the Opposition I rest much more assured knowing that such a body is charged with responsibility in this matter, and is doing its work so effectively. All honorable senators should feel indebted to the members of the committee for their work.

The thought has occurred to me that only on one prior occasion that I remember, during the period that I have been a member of this Senate, was any acute attention given to this question of the power to make delegated legislation. In 1944, towards the end of World War II., the Curtin Labour Government appointed a regulations advisory committee comprising Mr. A. D. Fraser, a member of the House of Representatives, as chairman, Mr. David Maughan, Mr. J. V. Barry - now Mr. Justice Barry of the Supreme Court of Victoria - and Dr. Frank Louat of the Sydney Bar. The three last-named gentlemen were very distinguished members of the legal profession. That committee was appointed for the main purpose of reviewing regulations made under the National Security Act, and to tender advice to the Government about what alterations might properly be made. It is relevant to the motion to indicate that they addressed themselves to three main matters, namely, the averment and onus of proof provisions - which honorable senators will remember formed a large part of the National Security Regulations - the use of answers obtained by compulsory interrogation, and the desirability of establishing reviewing committees. In my view those three matters fall completely and peculiarly within the jurisdiction of our own Senate standing committee, and I thought it might be as well to advert to the principles relating to those matters that were enunciated in the first report of the reviewing committee which was dated15th July, 1944. That committee submitted some six or seven reports in all, but this was the first and most important, and it was made public. Quite a number of the other reports were not made public. By reason of the principles enunciated here it might interest honorable senators and members of our own committee particularly, if I advert briefly to what was stated in that report. Paragraph 5 of the report reads -

quote.para: The committee accepts as fundamental the principles stated by Lord Sankey, Lord Chancellor, in his speech in Woolmington v. the Director of Public Prosecutions (35 A.C. 462) . . . where he said, "Throughout the web of the English Criminal Law one golden thread is always to be seen, that it is the duty of the prosecution to prove the prisoner's guilt . . subject . . . to any . . . statutory exception.If at the end of and on the whole of the case there is a reasonable doubt, created by the evidence given by either the prosecution or the prisoner . . . the prosecution has not made out a case and the prisoner is entitled to acquittal."

speech.para: Paragraph 6 reads -

quote.para: In order to apply this principle correctly, however, the observations of Sir James Fitzjames Stephen (" History of the Criminal Law", Vol. 1, page 354) should be borne in mind, namely - " In the present day the rule that a man is presumed to be innocent till he is proved to be guilty is carried out in all its consequences. The plea of not guilty puts everything in issue, and the prosecutor has to prove everything that he alleges from the very beginning. If it be asked why an accused person is presumed to be innocent, I think the true answer is, not that the presumption is probably true, but that society in the present day is so much stronger than the individual, and is capable of inflicting so very much more harm on the individual than the individual as a rule can inflict upon society, that it can afford to be generous. It is, however, a question of degree, varying according to time and place, how far this generosity can or ought to be carried."
Paragraph 8 reads -

The committee is of opinion accordingly that it is a principle to be departed from only in the most exceptional cases, that the onus, initial and final, of establishing the ingredients of an offence should rest upon the prosecution.
Then paragraph 9 reads -

It appears proper, however, and in no way inconsistent with the fundamental principles of the common law which have been devised for the protection of the community, that in respect of certain matters it should be permissible for the prosecutor to discharge the onus of introducing evidence by the use of the procedural device known as the " averment ". These are -

item.label: (a)
item.para: where the matter which the prosecution is required to prove is formal only and does not in itself relate to any conduct on the part of the defendant .

item.label: (b)
item.para: where the matter in question relates to conduct of the defendant alleged to constitute an ingredient in the offence charged and -

item.label: (i)
item.para: such matter is peculiarly within the knowledge of the defendant; and

item.label: (ii)
item.para: it is not reasonably practicable for the prosecutor to lead evidence to establish such matter.

quote.para: Unless the subject-matter can be shown to fall within either of these categories, however, the averment procedure should be resorted to only in a case where -

item.label: (a)
item.para: it is clear beyond doubt that the interests of the community require it; and

item.label: (b)
item.para: adequate safeguards are provided against any likelihood of administrative misuse.

quote.para: The committee then pointed out that each case has to be examined in its context, on its merits, and in the light of those principles that have been enunciated. It dealt at great length with individual national security regulations, and it made many proposals for the amendment of regulations relating to the averment clause, including its complete deletion in many cases. It recommended the abolition of the averment clause in the tea control regulations but recommended its retention in the prices control regulations. If any honorable senator is interested to ascertain why the distinction was drawn between the two cases, he might follow the matter up in the report. I believe that what 1 am putting now has certain relevant considerations for the committee in particular, and the Senate in general. It doss no harm to refresh our minds in this way about the principles underlying regulations and ordinances. At page 8 of the report the committee made an interesting recommendation in subparagraph (viii) in these terms -

Accordingly the Committee recommends that a proviso beadded to the regulation in or to the effect of the following terms: - " Provided that no averment shall be made unless the Crown Solicitor, the Assistant Crown Solicitor or a Deputy Crown Solicitor is satisfied that such averment is reasonably necessary for the due administration of justice and will not impose hardship upon or occasion injustice to the defendant."

The committee there sought to assure that somebody of judicial mind, legal training and responsible position would make a declaration in the terms recommended by the committee. I should say that it is a very salutory safeguard. Two other matters are referred to briefly in this report. One deals with the use of answers in circumstances where they have been compulsorily obtained.I shall read a brief extract from that topic from page 19 of the report. It is as follows: -

The Committee recognizes that it may be necessary and legitimate to require a person to produce accounts, books or documents, or to make a return, and to use any of such material, subject to the ordinary rules as to admissability, in proceedings against him. Powers of compulsory questioning, however, should be employed only for administrative purposes. Statements or disclosures mad by any person who is by virtue of any regulation required to answer any question or furnish any information (unless that information consists of books, accounts or documents or a return which he is required to make under the Regulations) should not, except in proceedings for perjury involved in such statement, or for making a wilfully false answer, or for refusal or failure to answer, be admissable against him in civil or criminal proceedings in any court.
The committee concludes-

The Committee recommends that either by addition to the regulations containing these powers, or by a regulation of generalapplication, provision should be made to protect in the manner indicated persons compelled under penalty to answer. As the position of the persons so interrogated would then be adequately protected, it would be proper to provide that he shall be not excused from answering on the ground that his answer might tend to incriminate him.

speech.para: The final matter with which the committee deals was the third one to which I adverted earlier, the question of the appointment of reviewing authorities. Paragraph 22 of the report is as follows: -

quote.para: The Committee has given careful consideration to the problem of establishing effective means of ensuring that some method of review shall be open to citizens affected by the exercise of administrative discretion.

speech.para: Et concludes with this comment -

quote.para: Each department which discharges the function of granting consents, licences, or permits to carry on businesses, should have associated with it a Reviewing Authority. That Reviewing Authority should consist of three members, with appropriate qualifications, who should be appointed by, and be directly responsible to the Minister and should hold office for a fixed period. The Reviewing Authority should function generally, however, and should not be brought into existence merely to deal with particular instances.

speech.para: With some degree of apology to the Senate I have raised these matters, but I have done so' because they deal with vital principles with which our own committee is concerned from time to time. I think it is well that now and again these principles should be given an airing, and some discussion promoted on the matters relating to them.
For the reasons I have given, I most cordially support the motion that the committee's report be printed.

talk.start.para: . - I support the motion, and I thank the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) for the extensive survey he has given of the paper, and also for his excursion into the examination of the report ot the Regulations Advisory Committee of 1944. The honorable senator need, not apologize to the Senate for doing so, because his remarks were apposite. At this time, it is well that the Senate should give some consideration to such questions as are raised by the report before the Senate, and also to the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition. The Senate is the place for discussions such as the present one.

speech.para: I disagree with the suggestion of the Leader of the Opposition that a joint committee would possibly be better for the consideration of regulations and ordinances. I am inclined to think that the Senate committee is the better body, and I am not alarmed at the fact that there is not a similar committee in the House of

Representatives. I regard the House of Representatives more as the Government House - that is, the House which is very close to three-quarters of the Ministry, whereas the Senate is the chamber more removed from the Ministry, lt is appropriate that there should be a more judicial consideration of regulations without pressure from Ministers, and such consideration can best be given by a Senate committee rather than by a joint committee. A joint committee, if it followed the usual pattern, would have twice as many members from the House of Representatives as from the Senate. Consequently, 1 disagree, in this mild manner, with the suggestion made by the Leader of the Opposition.

Before I pass to a consideration of tha report, let mc say that since I have been a member of this committee I have appreciated its approach to the work before it. That approach has been on entirely non-party lines. It has been encouraged by the enthusiasm of the members for the task in hand, and also by the enthusiasm of Mr. Bullock, the secretary of the committee, in obtaining details required by the committee.

The report before the Senate is unique in that it contains a transcript of evidence. I understand that that is a rare feature, but the committee, in its wisdom, when dealing with this Air Force regulation, felt that it was such an important matter that evidence of the - greatest value should be sought - that is, sworn evidence, and that it should be reported verbatim. As a consequence, the Senate has before it the sworn evidence of high-ranking civil servants in connexion with this regulation. I shall not trespass on the time of the Senate by traversing the grounds laid down by Senator McKenna as to the functions of the committee, because I want to stress some of the aspects of the evidence which may be of interest to honorable senators. Before doing so I point out that this Air Force regulation, as we discovered, had been evolved after many years of consideration. Apparently, some fifteen years ago the Treasury of the day indicated that a regulation should be made somewhat along the lines of that which was eventually made. The Army set its face against making such a regulation, but I understand that the Air Force and the Navy did make the regulations that are the subject of this report.

As a result of the committee's report the Air Force has withdrawn its regulation but the Department of the Army has not yet withdrawn a similar regulation. As the Minister for the Navy (Senator O'sullivan) is now seated at the table, I remind him that the committee is no doubt watching for the withdrawal of the Navy regulation as it is along the same lines as that of the Air Force. The committee feels that a wrong approach to the matter has been made by this Government and preceding governments, and I feel that I should invite the attention of the Senate to certain sections of the evidence which the committee took. I direct attention, first, to the evidence of Mr. Ewens, the acting Commonwealth Crown Solicitor, to be found at pages 44 and 45 of the record. As the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) explained in his remarks, the question at issue was whether the regula tion promulgated by the Air Board conflicted with a statute of this Parliament, namely, section 58 of the Defence Act. During the inquiry Senator Wright asked Mr. Ewens, the chief legal man at the disposal of the Government, the following question: -

quote.para: When the act says that section 58 of the act shall, subject to this act, continue to apply in relation to the Air Force, it is then your view, that, by virtue of that expression, it would be competent for the Executive to make regulations under the Air Force Act which would have the effect of completely negativing section 58?

speech.para: That means a regulation completely negativing the words of this Parliament. The answer given by Mr. Ewens was -

quote.para: Yes. I think that is perfectly clear from the act.

speech.para: That rather staggered the committee, that it would be possible for a Minister to cause regulations to be made which would completely negative a most important section of an act. Senator Wright came back to the same subject on page 45 of the record. He asked -

quote.para: And you would regard it as competent for a regulation to be made to this effect: " Section fifty-eight of the Defence Act shall not apply? "

speech.para: The answer was -
I think there are plenty of Air Force regulations which say that.
Senator Wright then continued ;
I am not concerned with that. You would regard it as competent for a regulation to say that section 58 of the Defence Act would not apply?
The answer was -

quote.para: Yes, clearly.

speech.para: That is rather frightening. 1 think it is important that the Senate should have placed before it the view of this trained adviser of the Government on the tremendous importance of a regulation made by a civil servant as against the sanctity, if I may put it that way, of a section of an act made by this parliament. Honorable senators will find this transcript of evidence worth reading because of the revealing facts that have been brought out.

I do not, at this stage, venture to make a suggestion as to whether Mr. Ewens is right or wrong, but the fact is that there is in evidence those words of his to which great weight should be given. I pass to another matter of somewhat less importance but which, nevertheless, is a challenge to the Government with regard to its legal services. It is apparent that there is tremendous pressure from time to time on the Crown Law Department and the Parliamentary Draftsman. The question arises as to why, when this regulation was promulgated, there was not included in it the power for some aggrieved person to appeal. Bit by bit it came out that the full operation of the regulation was in the process of being drafted. Mr. Ewens was quite frank. He said that the position was that his officers were not able to proceed- with the drafting immediately they received instructions. Then he disclosed that at the present time it takes about two months to proceed with the drafting because they have not anything like their authorized staff. He said it was almost impossible to get a suitable man to do this sort of work, that it takes years of training and they have not been able to get them for that reason. So, we find, thai right at this crucial point in our legislative machinery there is lack of trained staff. Unfortunately, the Attorney-General is not in the chamber at the moment, but I am sure that the Minister for National Development (Senator Spooner) will take this matter up urgently with the Parliamentary Draftsman and his colleagues to see that those officers who advise on these important matters, have an adequate trained staff.

One of the great needs in Australia ar the present time is to be able clearly to express legislative matters and regulations because the Australian community is developing to such an extent that a clear statement of these things is necessary. Long delays, because of lack of trained staff, should not be countenanced. It is the responsibility of the Government to make this trained staff available or, if necessary, to establish a small section of the Law School of Australia, possibly at the National University, for the training of adequate staff. Only the other day we were confronted with the estate duty regulations. This Senate, three years ago, passed an important amendment to the Estate Duty Act increasing the exemption from ?2,000 to ?5,000 in cases where the estate went to a widow, widower or a member of the family, and from ?1,000 to ?2,500 when the estate went to others. This Senate said that that exemption was to be made, lt was only during the course of the last parliamentary vacation that regulations were promulgated giving effect to that amendment. Consequently, there is a lag in the promulgation of regulations. As I have said, the reason for this lag may well be that sufficient staff for the purpose is not available. Surely, there can be no other answer, because the general public is entitled to relief from the furnishing of estate duty returns when this Parliament has lifted the exemption in such a remarkable way. Yet, the regulations have been promulgated only during the last few months, and possibly they are at this moment lying on the table of the Senate. Therefore, 1 consider that the reading of this report should be a rewarding experience to those members of the Senate who are able to read it; they will see that some very important functions of the executive should be carefully looked at. Accordingly, I support the motion, and 1 hope that the report, in its printed form, will be read by all members of the Senate.

talk.start.para: . - Before commenting on the contents of the report, I should like to make some general observations on the subject of subordinate legislation. The separation of powers in our parliamentary democracy is not, perhaps, commonly understood. We aver that we have a separation of the executive, the administration and the judiciary, but under our parliamentary system the separation is not so absolute as might be believed. In view of the modern development of the parliamentary institution, and the increasing importance of intervention by government in the business life of the community, perhaps that is just as well. In the United States of America, an attempt was made in the writing of the American constitution to make the separation complete. It is an interesting historical fact that, theoretically, the American constitution rested upon the treatise of a Frenchman name Montesquieu, who had studied the British system, but had completly misconceived the separation of powers. In turn, this treatise was translated into the American constitutional system. Even to-day, in Great Britain, the separation of powers is by no means complete. For example, the House of Lords is, at the one time, a political body, a parliamentary body, and at the same time, through one of its committees, a part of the judicial system of Great Britain. Furthermore, it will be seen that, in other circumstances, the courts of justice, by the exercise of their prerogative, interfere as it were, and intervene in the work of administrative tribunals. Similarly, the Crown still comes in, in a very intimate way, through the system of parliamentary government. Actually, the separation of powers is not nearly so complete as many people believe from the treatise of Montesquieu.

speech.para: Prior to the industrial revolution in Great Britain, the constitution and the functioning of Parliament were characterized by aloofness. Only major matters were considered fit and proper subjects for parliamentary scrutiny and attention, and there was little or no intervention by the Parliament in ordinary community life. But, with the growth of industrial power, and the arising from the industrial revolution of conditions that made the intervention of the Parliament more and more necessary, there was a major transition in the manner of thinking. One may read in the report of a select committee of the British House of Commons on Ministers' powers, a brilliant summary of the development that took place. The committee was under the chairmanship of Lord Donoughmore and many notable persons connected with British jurisprudence, including Sir William Holdsworth, served on it. The trend towards governmental intervention in community life is summed up in these words -

quote.para: The most distinctive indication of the change of outlook of the government of this country in recent years has been its growing preoccupation, irrespective of party, with the management of the' life of the people. A study of the Statute-book will show how profoundly the conception of the function of government has altered. Parliament finds itself increasingly engaged in legislation which has for ils conscious aim the regulation of the day-to-day affairs of the community, and now intervenes in matters formerly thought to be entirely outside its scope. This new orientation has its dangers as well as its merits. Between liberty and government there is an age-long conflict. lt is of vital importance that the new policy, while truly promoting liberty by securing better conditions of life for the people of this country, should not, in its zeal for interference, deprive them of their initiative and .independence which are the nation's most valuable assets.

speech.para: That is a succinct and complete summary of the new concept of government, and shows how the intervention by parliament in the lives of the people has made for the gradual improvement and betterment of their conditions. That, of course, could not be done solely by parliament. Once that kind of necessity is predicated, machinery must be established to meet it, and that was only done by the gradual extension of legislating bodies subordinate to the parliament itself. In that way subordinate legislation found its way into British parliamentary practice and life. There are many instances, going back to the time of- the Tudors, of the king having been empowered by proclamation virtually to repeal statutes. The Statute of Proclamation and the Statute of Wales were examples of subordinate legislation, under which tremendously wide and important powers were conferred. Nevertheless, a tremendous impetus was given to the growth of subordinate legislative bodies by the industrial revolution, culminating in the process referred to in the report by Lord Donoughmore's committee, to which I have referred. When we look at the modern scene, we see that that process has been accelerated and extended. But, just as it gives certain benefits, so does it have certain disadvantages and create certain responsibilities. It is with those responsibilities that the Parliament, particularly this chamber, is concerned, and we see an example in the report before us where this chamber, through one of its committees, has accepted its responsibility, and discharged it to the best of its capacity.

The functions of the parliament are distinct from those of a subordinate legislating body. The Parliament of Great Britain, of course, has absolute powers, within the limits of its constitutional abilities. Tt has been clearly said that that parliament can virtually do anything. The report of the committee on Ministers' powers states-

quote.para: Parliament is supreme and its power to legislate is therefore unlimited, lt can do the greatest things: it can do the smallest. It can make general laws for a vast Empire; it can make a particular exception out of them in favour of a particular individual. It can provide - and has in fact provided - for the payment of old-age pensions to all who fulfil the statutory conditions:

speech.para: It could also provide, and has in fact provided, for boiling the Bishop of Rochester's cook to death in oil. That was done in terms of a statute of Henry VIII. which says -

quote.para: It is ordained and enacted by authority of this present Parliament that the said Richard Rose shall be therefore boiled to death without having any advantage of his clergy.

speech.para: The same remedy is not available to us, although we should like to have it in certain circumstances in order to obtain justice against some of our culinary advisers. Subordinate legislative bodies, of course, have no such powers. The report to which 1 have referred goes on to say -

quote.para: But any power delegated by act of Parliament is necessarily a subordinate power because it is limited by the terms of the enactment whereby it is delegated.

speech.para: That is the overall basis on which this committee, operating on behalf of the Senate, has regarded the particular regulation which we are considering. As the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) pointed out when he opened the debate on this motion on behalf of the Opposition, the four canons of criticism, or prohibitions, on which the committee relies, and which it applies in the event of necessity, have all been virtually breached, so far as I can see, in this case. We can imagine that a regulation or some piece of minor or subsidiary legislation might violate one or, perhaps, two, or three of those canons, but this one appears to have violated all four of them.

Senator Laught dealt with one aspect of the committee's report and suggested that the evidence of the Assistant Solicitor-General, Mr. Ewens, throws grave doubts on whether this regulation complies with the terms of the statute under which it purports to be made. I know that Senator Wright, who may speak later in this debate, had firm views on that point during the deliberations of the committee and while it was taking evidence. He queried the actual legality of the regulation under the statute under which it was purporting to have been produced. Mr. Ewens ventured a contrary opinion. Senator Laught has referred to that point. If his opinion is correct, if it was contrary to the statute, then Canon No. 1 has been breached, as is suggested by Senator Wright. If Mr. Ewen's view is correct, if the regulation is completely competent within the statute, then we find that there are violations of the second, third and fourth canons of approach, which are the guides of the committee. If it is competent within the statute, then we find that by regulation it has been repealed - if not in law, certainly in fact - by the passing of what is a very clear and now long-standing statutory provision relating to this question of acts of members of the services occasioning loss or damage. We come then to Canon No. 3, which reads -

quote.para: That they do not unduly make the rights and liberties of citizens dependent upon administrative rather than upon judicial decisions.

speech.para: Whilst the committee is set up for other purposes it does assess the degree of guilt or culpability and arrives at its decisions in a judicial manner. Again, this is a violation of one of the canons of guidance which the committee adopts. Canon No. 4, which provides that regulations are concerned with administrative detail and do not amount to substantive legislation which should be a matter for parliamentary enactment, is violated.

I do not know whether honorable senators have examined the report very carefully, but it is one that requires some study in order to arrive at a definite opinion on the matter. It requires a study of the whole case in order to assess the degree to which the rights and liberties of individuals have been transgressed. A person does not cease to be a citizen of this Commonwealth nor is he placed in a very particular category because he happens to be a member of one of the armed services. That person is still entitled to his rights as an ordinary citizen of the Commonwealth, subject to any contractual limitations which he might impose upon himself by taking service with the Crown in one of the services in a particular capacity. Section 58 of the Defence Act, which purports to have been applied to the Air Force Act, says that if a person is entrusted with Commonwealth property and, by his conduct or default, loses it, or damages it, then damage may be recovered against him by action in a court of law. As the Leader of the Opposition has pointed out, if such a thing happens, it is mandatory upon the Crown to follow that type of recovery procedure.

Section 58 was specifically carried and applied to the Air Force and, in addition, a regulation virtually in terms of section 58, was written into the Air Force regulations. So, when regulation 515 emerged, we had section 58, and we had regulation 435, which applied to Commonwealth property in the custody of a member of the Air Force. It provided that the mode of recovery should be by ordinary processes through the civil court. Then, regulation 515 intervenes and goes far beyond that. First of all, it no longer confines the offence to Commonwealth property. It could clearly apply to property that did not belong to the Commonwealth. I have canvassed this matter. I instanced the hypothetical case in which a member of the Air Force, contrary to instructions, might be flying over a farm below a prescribed minimum ceiling, and frighten some animals, causing damage which could result in a claim for damage by the owner of the stock against the Commonwealth. The claim might be acknowledged by the Commonwealth which would pay the damage and then in turn seek recovery from the member of the Air Force. In that case, no Commonwealth property was involved at all. It was the property of a third party altogether. It was a complete extension of this principle beyond the limited principle previously contained in section 58 and repeated in regulation 435. I mention this as one of the matters that has occurred to me as being worthy of serious consideration. In my view, it is a dangerous aspect of the regulation.

Normally, if an airman or any member of the Defence Forces is charged with a breach of the regulations or an offence against the Defence Act, procedures for the determination of his guilt, trial and punishment or his exoneration are provided but. in this case, if damage was caused in the circumstances I have indicated, it was not necessary for the Air Board to take any action against him as it would have been required to do if it were merely alleging the offence. All that was necessary was to establish the claim for damages against him to the Air' Board, in the course of which the relevant authority would necessarily determine the offence and whether he was innocent or guilty. Therefore, there was, in fact, a by-passing of the whole procedure of alleging and determining offences committed against air force regulations or the Defence Act.

For these, and many other reasons, the committee thought that the continuance of this regulation was contrary to the statute, and transgressed the principles to which the committee always adverts, and which are the beacons by which it guides its deliberations and determinations. We believe that this report, apart from the immediate effect of removing an injustice, might stimulate an interest and regard in this chamber for the matters which are the particular concern of the Senate and are of growing importance in the community.

As I said earlier, we can expect this process to continue, and it has many advantages. For example, it allows things to be done which the Parliament could not possibly do, having regard to the modern complexities of life. It provides a certain flexibility in political and parliamentary administration. The passing of regulations and the granting of powers to minor bodies also enables technical matters to be handled by bodies that are most competent to do that work. They can deal with matters which would be quite unsuitable for the particular and detailed consideration of the Parliament. It enables a certain amount of experimentation to take place in the sense that we might deal by regulation with a town planning scheme. If it is not altogether suitable, it is possible to alter or amend the relevant regulation to provide an alternative scheme. If such a scheme were to come before the Parliament to be considered and adopted, it could not, even if unsuitable, be resurrected before the Parliament and considered within a reasonable time.

Therefore, there is a tremendous demand for the extension of this kind of legislation but, as 1 have said, correlative to the demand is the duty and the responsibility it brings with it. That duty and responsibility must always be in the forefront of the minds of members of Parliament to ensure that the liberty of the individual is not unduly assailed, and that it is involved only where public interest demands that the liberty of the individual shall be sacrificed in whole or in part; to ensure that that shall be clearly understood and determined by the Parliament, and that the Parliament shall legislate in the minor things in the clear and distinct terms of the enabling statute.

Apart from the ad hoc value of this report in the discontinuance of the relevant regulation, it has been an encouragement to the committee itself. The committee has always functioned, to some extent, on general principles. This is one of the most specific results that has flowed from the committee during the years that I have been identified with it. We can confidently expect that the same result will be obtained if the same processes are applied to other regulations that are extant or might be prepared at any time. This will inspire the committee to more continuous and closer scrutiny of relevant matters.

Members of the committee appreciate the action of the Government in responding so quickly to the obvious logic of the committee's report and the points which it expressed. It is encouraging that when a case is objectively presented and, in sound common sense, is virtually unanswerable, there should be no dispute or hesitancy about taking the proper executive action. That action is an encouragement to the committee, and I congratulate the Minister on his personal and ready response to this report. Such action is not easily taken by a Minister, and we congratulate him on his promptitude.

I commend this report, and the motion, to honorable senators, and urge a study of this very important field of minor and subsidiary legislation which is having such a marked effect on modern life. We should ensure that that effect is achieved only with justice to the individual, and not with injustice which escapes the scrutiny of the elected representatives.

talk.start.para: .- I wish to thank the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) for the kindly references he made to the work of the Regulations' and Ordinances Committee. As Senator Byrne has said, the committee has been functioning continuously, and has furnished reports from time to time. It is a joint committee, but each member of it goes to work solely to apply, in a non-party spirit. the formula set down for the criticism of rules and regulations. When we sit at the table, party political affiliations are forgotten. 1 was appointed to the committee when I was elected to the Senate in 1949, and although honorable senators have not often seen occasions for action such as that contained in this report, I can assure them that the committee has met regularly. Of course, if the committee has no objection to a rule or regulation before it, it has nothing to say in that connexion. Most of the rules, regulations and ordinances before the committee are accepted. Only on a rare occasion is there need for the committee to act. In this case the committee saw the need to act, and it did so.

speech.para: The Leader of the Opposition has said that the only previous occasion on which he remembers action by the committee was that taken by the Ordinances Committee of 1944. Since I have been a member of the committee, we have brought before the Minister concerned matters to which we felt attention should be directed. For example, I remember the matter of the licences regulations in regard to imported goods. In that case the committee made a comprehensive report in which it stated that it considered that such matter should be dealt with by way of more substantial legislation. The then Minister did not agree, but we brought that matter forward and indicated our views very strongly. Later, we dealt with the onus of proof in the Health Act, and directed the attention of the then Minister for Health to it. Later, we discovered that the whole of the Health Act had been introduced in three sections by way of regulation, and we drew the attention of the then Minister for Health to that matter and indicated that we considered that health should be dealt with by parliamentary legislation. The Minister agreed that our views were correct, and, as a result of the work of the committee, he brought down legislation which is now the Health Act. Therefore, honorable senators will perceive that the committee has been functioning energetically. Whilst its work may not readily be seen, on the rare occasions that its reports come before this chamber honorable senators are reminded that it is working continuously on the business of the Parliament.

The committee has the advantage of the advice of a legal adviser who is provided by the Government. He gives us his views and we study them, put forward our ideas and make up our minds on all the material before us. So, it is quite clear that this committee goes exhaustively into all the matter that comes before it. Perhaps I should also say that its members carry out their duties excellently, because they represent a very good cross-section of all parties in the Senate. A former Attorney-General, Senator Spicer, considered this committee of great importance, and the weight that the opinions of the committee carry indicates the valuable contributions made by its members. At present, I am the chairman of the committee, and there are six other members. Of those, three are legal practitioners - Senator Byrne, Senator Laught and Senator Wright. Senator Seward, another member, is also a member of the Public Accounts Committee and has had the benefit of wide experience in parliamentary life in Western Australia. He is much interested in all investigation work. Senator Arnold represents the Opposition on the committee, and we all know that he is a man of considerable merit. He has contributed greatly to our discussions. The legal members of the committee are particularly valuable, because the work of the committee demands that some of its members should have a legal knowledge. As a layman, I find it valuable to have the advantage of legal opinions on the committee.

talk.start.para: - What about me?

- In running through -the list of members of the committee I inadvertently overlooked Senator Willesee. Although he is one of the youngest senators in this chamber, he has been a member of this committee since the present Government assumed office in 1949, and he has applied himself most diligently to its work. There is no doubt that honorable senators look upon this committee as an important one, but all honorable senators who have so far spoken on the motion, with the exception of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna), have been members of tile committee. Perhaps, our work should bring more response from senators outside the committee. We should be glad to know what they think about our activities.

speech.para: This committee is similar to other committees of the Parliament in that it watches the interests of the people and the Parliament generally. The Public Accounts

Committee is doing a very good job in ensuring that this Parliament shall get value for the money that it allocates for various purposes. That committee travels round the Commonwealth to decide whether proposed public works are necessary and whether, if they are proceeded with, the Government will get full value for its money.
