That committee, like the Public Accounts Committee, does a very good job for the Parliament and the people. The Committee on Regulations and Ordinances is of a similar nature, and watches over the rulemaking power of the Parliament. It is designed to ensure that Ministers and departments do not sidestep the rule-making powers of the Parliament. If a Minister or a department wants to get something done but does not want to run the gauntlet of a debate in Parliament, it is easy to make a regulation. This committee watches all such regulations, and, where necessary, brings them to the attention of the Parliament. If we keep in mind the simple fact that the purpose of the committee is to ensure that in cases where substantial legislation is needed it should be introduced; and if this committee is ever watchful of the content of all regulations brought before it, it will continue to succeed in its duty to safeguard the rights of the Parliament. If this committee were not functioning, regulations and ordinances that should not be passed might slip through and honorable senators would be none the wiser. Therefore, the committee is of real value not only to the Senate and the Parliament, but also to the people of Australia. As a result, the members of the committee have not only rendered valuable service, but in doing so have also received important knowledge of parliamentary procedure relating to these matters and of the working of departments and of the Parlia.ment generally. 1 have been pleased to hear the praise which has been bestowed on this committee to-day. I hope that its lay members will speak on this report. As chairman, 1 can confidently say that the members of the committee have been both able and active. lt is a body which will always be mindful of the rights of Parliament in relation to > emulation-making and will ensure that regulations shall not be evaded or sidestepped h\ Ministers or departments. I thank the Leader of the Opposition (Senator
McKenna) and other honorable senators who have spoken, for their praise of the committee's work.

talk.start.para: . - It is with some diffidence that I rise to speak to the motion because of the praise which the chairman of the committee has given to its members. As far as 1 can recollect, it is many years since a report of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee has received such a welcome in the Senate. Usually such a document is received in a formal manner, and is pushed out of the way as quickly as possible, but on this occasion several honorable senators have contributed to the debate on the motion that it be printed. This discussion can be of great value to the Senate.

speech.para: The particular regulation which was the subject of investigation and report by the Senate committee might easily have escaped attention and become law in Australia. Honorable senators are aware that vast numbers of regulations are made from time to time, but over the years the inadequate scrutiny which they have received must make honorable senators realize that a government, by regulation, can take to itself substantial powers more properly belonging to Parliament. For a long time. I was labouring under the delusion that these regulations were properly examined before they were submitted to Parliament for approval, but when I heard the evidence given by the Parliamentary Draftsman before the committee in connexion with this matter, I was rudely awakened. He said that, frequently, departments would disregard his advice. I was under the impression that in a regulation certain action might need to be covered and that the Minister and his advisers would consult the draftsman as to the extent of its ambit and form. As a consequence, only by a mistake would any regulation be drafted which would not be in conformity with the requirements of parliamentary procedure. It was revealing to hear the draftsman say that it was possible for Ministers and heads of departments to disregard his advice and make regulations which did not conform with what he believed to be the proper form. This evidence underlined the importance of the task placed on the Regulations and Ordinances Committee and its responsibility. to be certain that all regulations be carefully examined and brought before the Senate for approval or disallowance. The committee has to consider whether the power taken by regulation has legislative sanction or whether the powers of the Parliament are being properly exercised.

During this session the committee has discovered that the Government had promulgated two or three regulations in which it considered the Government arrogated to itself greater powers than they ought to have. The committee recommended that one of the regulations, which is dealt with in this report, should be disallowed. Another is under consideration and will probably be placed before the Senate. Some attempt should be made to work out a code which could be followed to make certain that powers are not being taken from the Senate and that the scrutiny of regulations by this Parliament is not treated too lightly.

In the evidence given before the committee in connexion with the regulation which is the subject of this report, matters were brought to our notice which appear to have been disregarded year after year, but which call for some action by this House. This regulation had its origin in 1943-44, when the Auditor-General made certain comments concerning the running of the armed services and suggested that there ought to be a tightening up in some of their administrative affairs. Since that time the Auditor-General has brought forward this matter on several occasions, but it is more than ten years since he first asked for a regulation or some corrective measure to be applied to the accounting of losses in the armed services. This regulation was adopted by the Royal Australian Air Force to meet that requirement. Although, ten or twelve years ago, the Auditor-General referred an anomaly to Parliament, the Parliament has not taken the necessary action to correct it. That reveals that insufficient attention is being given to the administration of some government agencies. However, it is one of those facets of government that appears to be nobody's task, is allowed to drift, and is revealed only in an inquiry of the nature which was conducted on this particular regulation. The Senate is a proper chamber to devote a good deal more time to the committee procedures of this Parliament.

I have stressed from time to time the desirability of the Senate setting up a number of committees. My mind goes back to my suggestion that a committee be appointed to inquire into national development. The establishment of a committee such as this could give continuing policy to this Senate.

Regulations which come before the Parliament are looked into by this committee of the Senate, but I feel that the committee does not devote enough time in its deliberations in order to give the regulations and ordinances the scrutiny that they need. Over the years my experience has been that this is one of the committees, the sittings of which are fitted in between the odd hours of the Parliament. It ought, like other committees, allot certain days for the care of its particular task.

In a debate of this nature I think we might engage in a general review of the work of the Senate in matters appertaining to the Parliament itself, and into the better ways of conducting the Parliament. The Regulations and Ordinances Committee can do a great deal to bring to the notice of the members of the Senate and of the Parliament matters that are of tremendous importance, particularly if they are allowed to escape the scrutiny of the Parliament and the public. The regulation that we proposed should be withdrawn was rightly withdrawn by the Minister. It was obvious that the regulation ought not to have been made, and that somewhere in its drafting sufficient thought had not been given to the importance of what it contained. If we allow the Government, by Executive action, to take to itself all sorts of power and then rely upon a committee, meeting at odd moments, to audit the work of the Executive, I feel it is a little too much to expect that committee to uncover all of the maladministration that may occur through regulations and ordinances. I am very pleased that to-day the Senate has deemed it worthwhile to spend an hour or so discussing the general problem associated with the committee.

I agree with Senator Wood, the chairman of the committee, that honorable senators who were not actually connected with the committee should express their views on its work and point out how it can be. furthered in any way. T should like them to scrutinize the way in which we are carrying out our parliamentary life to see whether it is not possible for this Senate to play an even more important part than it is playing at the moment.

talk.start.para: .- I enter this debate in response to the remarks of Senator Wood, the chairman of the committee, and of Senator Arnold, who suggested that honorable senators not in any way connected with the committee should appraise its work. I often hear of people coming into this chamber and on seeing a number of vacant seats ask, "Where are the senators? Where have they gone?" Their minds generally run in one channel; they think that honorable senators are in the bar or the billiard room when, in fact, honorable senators are acting as the watchdogs of democracy as members of so many of these committees which they attend during the day. If honorable senators look at the back of the notice-paper they will -see the number of committees which we have in this chamber. Thirteen appear on the notice-paper and there are many party committees which do very sound work.

speech.para: When honorable senators consider the personnel of this committee they must acknowledge that it is a very worthwhile -committee. I think that the chairman, after listening to his eulogy, will have to remain in that position for the next twenty years. I do not know whether he will get the support of Senator Willesee, who is the only senator about whom there would be any doubt. I say quite seriously and genuinely that during the six years I have been here these regulations have been a puzzle to any lay man. The committee, in scrutinizing these regulations, acts as a warning to a wanton Minister who likes to govern by regulation and who does not wish to bring his work to the scrutiny of the Parliament.

talk.start.para: - Some governments, too, are carried on by regulation.
- In saying that, I am assuming that Ministers are part of a government.
- Some governments are guilty of doing that, too.

- I agree with the honorable senator. We laymen in the "Senate are indebted to those senators who carry out this work. It is not an easy job to scrutinize, dissect and analyse these rather dry regulations, but it is most important work indeed. The manner in which this regulation was so quickly withdrawn must have brought home to the members of the committee that in this one case, at any rate, they had put their finger on a regulation which should have been more carefully scrutinized before it was placed before the Parliament and before it came before the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. I have not anything else to say. I felt that one or two honorable senators who were not members of the committee and who appreciate the work of the committee should say, " Well, we think it has done a good job ". Indeed, we might say that while it does its work so well, it lets some of us out from reading these regulations at all.

. - I desire to be brief because 1 think that just about everything that can possibly be said has been said. I want to underline one or two things connected with the action taken by the committee on this occasion which was somewhat different from that taken on former occasions. I think it is the first time that evidence has been called before the committee, and examination and cross-examination conducted over a long period of time. It was most revealing and one of the most interesting crossexaminations to which I have listened.

speech.para: One of the most interesting things connected with this regulation was, as Senator Arnold pointed out, that it took twelve or thirteen years for it to come to fruition, only to be disallowed by the Minister himself. Rather than that being the case of a Minister trying to be over-ambitious in the running of his department, it happened quite accidentally. It was most interesting, as the cross-examination proceeded and the evidence was pieced together, to discover that when departments tried to move into a field where they could take to themselves more control over the recovery of money, each one of the three departments, acting quite properly and moving towards what they thought was something desirable, at no stage, as was disclosed by cross-examination by Senator Wright, gave specific consideration to the interests of a third party. The moment we move into the third party field, we give power to the departments, to recover unknown amounts of money outside the present processes of law. I mention this aspect of the matter because it becomes more interesting as each department puts forward its conception of matters at their various stages in the department.

Over the years, I have noticed another alarming trend in government departments, in that they defend not only the action token right to the last letter, but also the methods that were used. Any department can avoid the scrutiny of this committee by -means of the responsible Minister making a :substantive motion in the Parliament, whereupon the regulation is immediately excluded because it does not come, within our purview. As I have said, all along the line the ^departments have not only defended what they did, but also the manner in which they did it, stoutly contending that they were 100 per cent, right. In the final analysis, as Senator Arnold has pointed out, in the present instance the Minister agreed with the committee and disallowed the regulation.

I come now to an aspect of the matter that was raised by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna), but with which no other speaker has dealt. He suggested that, in addition to our committee, a similar committee should be appointed by the House of Representatives. 1 do not see the necessity for that. In my opinion, it is necessary for only one parliamentary committee to scrutinize regulations. I believe that a committee of the Senate is preferable to a committee of the House of Representatives for this purpose. Furthermore, Standing Order 36A. (4.) provides -

quote.para: All Regulations and Ordinances laid on the Table of the Senate shall stand referred to such Committee for consideration and, if necessary, report thereon . . .

speech.para: Although the prescribed period of fifteen days has elapsed and a regulation has become law, it still stands referred to this mittee - as regulations passed from twenty to 30 years ago still stand referred - and the committee can report on it at any time. As I have said, we cannot disallow a regulation after the prescribed period of fifteen days has elapsed, but any regulation or ordinance can be reviewed by the committee at any time.
Seeing that congratulations are the order of the day, I should like to refer to the two outstanding young officers of the Senate,

Messrs. Odgers and Bullock, who successively have performed sterling service in the capacity of secretary to the committee. In spite of the kudos that we have taken to ourselves to-day, I believe that the enthusiasm that has been engendered by this committee is largely attributable to the efforts of these two officers. I understand that, in future, another officer of the Senate will act in this capacity; the other two officers whom I have mentioned have set him a high standard to emulate. Over the years, various members of this chamber have advocated the appointment of committees in connexion with national development and other matters. The results that have been achieved by the Standing Regulations and Ordinances Committee proves the value of committees of this chamber.

talk.start.para: . - I rise mainly to congratulate the Regulation and Ordinances Committee on the report that it has presented, and to which I have looked forward for a long time. There was a stage when we thought that all laws were made by the Parliament except the common law, and that a person was not bound to comply with a law that was not covered by statute. However, some years ago a former Chief Justice of England wrote a great book on this subject. I know that it was a great book, because he said so himself; he so described it to a friend of mine at a dinner. In that book, he described the new method of government as the new despotism. We all, no doubt, remember when we became members of this chamber how we were appalled by the number of regulations in existence, and were concerned at our inability to understand them. I am convinced that the best means of our understanding the regulations is to have a committee to study them and direct our attention to certain aspects of them. I agree with Senator Willesee that this is a proper function of the Senate, in which there is a somewhat different atmosphere from that of the other place. Of course, we know that the fate of the Government depends on votes in the other place; it could depend on a sudden vote, and therefore the party spirit is always very high in the House of Representatives. It need not be so high in this chamber. In general, I think that we discuss matters with a good deal more calm and deliberation. This is a subject that should be discussed in such a way. ft is wise, too, that our attention should be directed to certain matters by Senate committees because, in a sense, those committees constitute the eyes and ears of this chamber. Our committees are able, as a result of their inquiries, to submit to this chamber certain conclusions which can form the basis of a proper debate. Therefor, I hope that all honorable senators will support the establishment of additional committees, not to be a nuisance to the Administration, but to assist the calm consideration of various matters by the Senate.

talker.role: Attorney-General and Minister for the Navy
talker.name: O'SULLIVAN, Neil
Senator O'SULLIVAN

talk.start.para: . - Although I was not Attorney-General when the report under discussion was presented, I should tike to congratulate the committee on it. I want to make it clear that the specific regulation with which the report deals substantially was rescinded. That action was due to the vigilance of the committee in bringing to the notice of the Senate and of the responsible Minister, certain aspects of the regulation. The legality of it, and whether it was ultra vires or intra vires, was not a determining factor. The regulation was withdrawn by the Government, as a matter of policy and without any hesitation when attention was directed to its full effect. That emphasizes the importance of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, because it is quite a simple matter for a regulation which, on its face appears innocuous, to be devastatinglydangerous. Perhaps, if the Ministers themselves exercised greater vigilance in the scheme of things that would not happen. However, the committee has more than justified its existence by bringing to the notice of the Senate the implications of regulations which are subsequently disallowedby the Government.I trust that the committee will continue to exercise similar vigilance in the future.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Sitting suspended from 5.35 to 8 p.m.

debate.para: Debate resumed from 24th May (vide page 1002), on motion by Senator Marriott -
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the present practice of broadcasting the proceedings of the

Commonwealth Parliament should either cease or be varied to provide for the broadcasting of portions only of those proceedings, such as question time in both Houses and important speeches in either House; and thatthis resolution be forwarded for the consideration of the Government.

talk.start.para: . - The motion before the Senate is one that was moved by Senator Marriott before the Parliament rose for the recess. I followed it very carefully at the time and noted his main points. I think he is to be commended for raising the issue, after ten years of experience of broadcasting, and for the amount of thought that he quite obviously devoted to his subject.I remind the Senate of the terms of his motion. Senator Marriott himself rejected his alternative for selective broadcasting of the proceedings of either House. He realized the grave difficulties involved in determining what was important and what was less important, and, accordingly, I do not devote any argument to that alternative at all. I now find the motion is one which seeks for the complete cessation of parliamentary broadcasts, and I propose to proceed on that basis.

speech.para: I agree with very much of what Senator Marriott said, but my feeling is that he seemed to be more concerned with the mechanics of operating the broadcasting system than with the broad fundamental principle that underlies the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings. From the notes that I made at the time when he spoke - I regret I have not had time adequately to refresh my mind from the report of his speech - I should like to deal seriatim with the points he raised. I think his first was that the microphone rules Parliament. He gave a number of instances which, in his view, justified that claim. For instance, he pointed to the fact that whereas in preradio days the budget would be delivered at 3 p.m., it is now broadcast at 8 p.m.. at what is known as the prima donna hour. He says that important second-reading speeches are reserved for the same hour on the air. What he says is true, but I think that those facts are an automatic and rather necessary adjustment to the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings. I think that if either House has the opportunity of reaching a very wide audience it is surely the most natural thing in the world for either the Government or an-

Opposition to seek to broadcast its viewpoint at a time when it may reasonably be expected that the greatest audience will be available. I admit the soft impeachment thai trie business is so arranged, but surely that is only accommodating Parliament to the new system. I can see no objection to that at all.

Senator Marriott points out that the debates are interrupted at 5.45 p.m. to enable something regarded as of more importance to come on at 8 p.m. When all parties conspire to that end, when the Government and the Opposition collaborate to that end - it is nearly always a matter of complete agreement; even the scattering of the broadcasts between the two Houses of Parliament is largely a matter of agreement - surely that is no justification for claiming that the microphone rules the Parliament. I think it is merely a necessary adjustment that flows from the fact that broadcasting has to be established.

His next point was that the Senate meekly gives in to the House of Representatives. I do not think that is the case. The Senate is only half the size of the House of Representatives. It sits for approximately only about half the time, and accordingly, in the ordinary course of events, one would not expect that it would be allowed quite the same broadcasting time; but under the present system of broadcasting, when one examines what the Joint Parliamentary Committee, which is in charge of the whole matter under the act establishing it, has decided, 1 think very little exception can be taken to the present system. Even on the notes of broadcasts for this week, as I recall it, the arrangement is for Tuesday for the House of Representatives, Wednesday for the Senate, Thursday for the House of Representatives and Friday for the Senate. In actual fact, and in actual allocation, two days are allowed to each chamber each week. If the Senate prized the air so highly and regarded it as a dominating factor, it could easily arrange its business to sit on Wednesday, Thursday and Friday and so have two days instead of one out of its three for broadcasting. It could quite easily do that, but, of course, the Senate lines the two up, apportions their values, considers its own convenience, and says. " It is more important that we return to our electorates, that we have time to travel, to reach them, and to prepare for the work of next week than to stay for the privilege of broadcasting ".

talk.start.para: - There are other factors also.

- I do not know what they are. I think the main factor would be the convenience of senators themselves; that would be the dominating factor. If 1 am right in suggesting that, as 1 think 1 am, then surely the Senate does not rate broadcasting so highly after all. That, in my view, is the best argument against Senator Marriott's proposal that the microphone rules Parliament. I think that is the clearest answer to it. If the Senate was so radioconscious, it would undoubtedly sit on Friday, a day which has been reserved for its use on the air.

speech.para: Then, Senator Marriott brackets two more items. I admit his soft impeachment here. He says that the Government puts on items that favour it and that the Opposition save adjournment motions for days when the Senate ' is on the air. That is perfectly true. What is more natural than that? After all is said and done, it is human nature to seek the best advantage for oneself. Is it not also the duty of a Government, putting its viewpoint, and of an Opposition putting its own outlook, to seek what each considers to be the most advantageous broadcasting time for the purpose? I admit that it is an incident of the system, but I think it is a very natural, very human, and I should say a very proper one. The mere fact that that is so doss not justify the claim that the microphone rules Parliament.

Senator Marriott also claimed that the broadcast ceases at the moment when the adjournment motion is moved. That is true. No speeches on the adjournment are broadcast, and I think there is a very good reason for that. Adjournment time is the danger time when any topic might be introduced. That is the time when, if the proceedings were broadcast, there would be the greatest danger of the privileges of Parliament being abused in order to make personal attacks on people, perhaps not within the Parliament, for one reason and another. We have had a good deal of experience of that. I think that it is wise that it should end. Another factor to be considered in connexion with that is that the adjournment takes place late in the evening. On some days, the Senate has sat morning, afternoon and night, and the temptation, if the proceedings were being broadcast when the adjournment was moved, would be to elongate the proceedings unduly, and perhaps carry them into the small hours of the morning. I think there is a good deal of common sense as well as a sound basis for not broadcasting the proceedings on the adjournment. After all, the Standing Orders lay down certain rules for determining when business comes on and how it is to be conducted. No one has notice of what is to be said on the adjournment. A person may be attacked, whether he is functioning inside or outside the Parliament. He might not have any warning of the attack. The forms of the Parliament are designed to enable sufficient notice to be given of the business that is coming forward. That is an additional reason why the proceedings on the adjournment should not be broadcast.

It is true, as Senator Marriott has said, that honorable senators have accommodated themselves to the introduction of radio broadcasts by agreeing to limit their speeches, when the Senate is being broadcast, to half an hour for all except leaders and Ministers whereas, under the Standing Orders, they are entitled to an hour. After all is said and done, speeches are improved by being condensed into half an hour, although I offend against brevity myself. I cannot get my speeches down to smaller proportions, and I regret that because I regard it as a defect. I think that speeches are more compact, more interesting and far more easy on the ear if they are not drawn out over a period of an hour. That arrangement to limit speeches was not only fair, but was also a distinct advantage in that it tended to improve the debates in this chamber. It gave everybody an opportunity to speak to the electors. At this stage I must say that the gentleman's agreement that was made between the Opposition and the Government has, with the rarest and most accidental exceptions, been honoured most scrupulously.

I agree entirely with Senator Marriott that, when State elections are pending, there is a tendency to turn the Parliament into a medium for propaganda. It really becomes an electioneering platform for the State elections.

talk.start.para: - This is a States HouseSenator McKENNA. - Frankly, I do not think that justifies members of the National Parliament stepping down from a consideration of national questions to enter the realm of State politics. I think we disfigure our proceedings by doing so. I am not thinking of anything in particular in this connexion.. The fault lies everywhere. I do not see, however, how a standing order could be drawn that would effectively prevent that sort of occurrence. I do not think such proceedings could be forbidden by a standing order, but if 1 thought that could be done,I would be in favour of it.I consider the present arrangement is a bad feature and" one that promotes acrimony. Such discussions are not strictly the business of the National Parliament.

speech.para: The second principal point made by Senator Marriott was that the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings damaged the prestige of the Parliament. If that is the case, it is not a reflection upon the fact that Parliament is broadcast, but upon those who are using the broadcasting system; that is, the members of Parliament themselves. In this Parliament we speak from what I regard as the highest forum in Australia. We reach an audience of the widest possible character. We are speaking to the young, the middle aged and the elderly, and I believe there is a grave responsibility upon us all not only to exhibit good manners and good behaviour in our relations with one another, but also to refrain studiously from scandal and slander which, once uttered, cannot be recalled. One could not reach the same audience again even if one wanted to make amends. Therefore, insofar as there are difficulties in the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings, such as those I have mentioned, I suggest that we should not blame the broadcasting, but those who misuse it. The remedy lies entirely in our own hands. It is for us to improve our public relations, and to observe good standards of behaviour.

The third point made by Senator Marriott was that the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings was distasteful to the public, and that a majority of the listeners did not want consistent broadcasting of Parliament. Senator Marriott gave a few reasons for that point of view, and spoke of the need for a good voice and for oratory.. He said that there was much repetition as between the House of Representatives and the Senate. I believe that a good voice and oratory are helpful to those who speak over the air, but they are outweighed by two things - by a thoughtful speech and by sincerity. Those two qualities will always command an audience rather than the mere mechanics of voice, delivery and formal presentation. I do not deny that those qualities are helpful, but I do not think they are the principal attractions for the listener.

I know that there is a good deal of noise in both chambers while speeches are being broadcast. The microphone magnifies noise. I have listened on a number of occasions, and could hear many background noises and conversations which were more audible to a listener than they were to a speaker in this chamber. That is irritating and disconcerting. It is distracting enough to be speaking in this chamber while honorable senators nearby are conversing. They do so without thought, and I am sure that some of us do not realize the strength and carrying power of our own voices. We engage in that practice ourselves, but if we were listening to the effects over the air, we might be frightened to know how those side conversations are going over to the public and how disturbing they are to listeners.

Senator Marriott referred to the cost of broadcasting the Parliament for some 600 hours a year. I believe that it is not possible to make an accurate estimate of the cost. The fact is that the Parliament takes over a second network when its proceedings are being broadcast. I admit the justice of the complaint by persons in remote areas who have only one radio channel, and who' have no option but to listen to Parliament while the proceedings are being broadcast. They are cut off from their normal entertainment. That is a ground for legitimate complaint. The proper answer might well be to set up an entirely new channel for the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings as soon as the Parliament can afford the cost. It is rather a pity to disturb well-established programmes which are broadcast on normal channels. Many people are creatures of habit and are disturbed when their mode of life has to be re-arranged. That would make them resentful of parliamentary broadcasts.

I was horrified at the thought that Senator Marriott might be correct when he said that this Parliament might seek television broadcasting one of these days. I shall not be interested in that proposal. I say quite frankly that the days upon which the proceedings of the Senate are broadcast are comfortable neither for me nor for the Whip. Honorable senators are seeking the most advantageous hour to speak, and I am more sorry for the Whip than for myself. There is an atmosphere of propaganda about the speeches on the days that we are being broadcast. The atmosphere in the chamber is tense, and tempers are prone to i. se far more quickly than is the case on other days. The Senate is least objective when the proceedings in this chamber are being broadcast. Although I am a strong advocate of the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings for reasons that I shall give, if I were considering my own comfort, I would wish that our proceedings' were not broadcast. 1 am more comfortable on an occasion like this when I can be objective and talk quietly to the Senate, disregarding the outside audience. If it were a matter of personal taste T should be in Senator Marriott's corner in this matter, but while radio broadcasting is here we have to put up with the propaganda and tension that is involved. After all is said and done they are mere incidents of the system, and we have to take the good with the bad in this relatively new medium.

The broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings is in its very early stages. Late this evening I had put into my hand a pamphlet written by Dean McHenry, of the University of California at Los Angeles in America. That gentleman is the dean of political science at that university, and he has written. a most interesting brochure on the broadcasting of parliamentary debates in New Zealand and Australia. In it he has stated that Australia and New Zealand are perhaps the only two countries in the world that broadcast parliamentary proceedings regularly. Perhaps, the Senate would be interested in part of the introduction of his book which reads -

quote.para: Ever since radio became common, recurring suggestions have been made that the medium ought to be used to carry the debates of legislative bodies directly to the body politic. As Sir William Haley once aptly put it:

Parliament is the keystone of the arch of our democracy. Broadcasting is the most comprehensive, simultaneous, and ubiquitous means yet invented of communicating with the people. It is natural that from the beginning they should have taken a lively interest in each other.
Although frequently proposed elsewhere, only New Zealand and Australia broadcast their national parliamentary proceedings on an extensive and regular basis.

The legislative assembly of Saskatchewan is on the air for a limited period each legislative day; various American state legislatures and local councils have experimented with television and radio; special events have long been broadcast from the American Congress, and more recently spectacular Senate committee hearings have been televised; important West-German Parliamentary proceedings occasionally are transmitted on both radio and television.

speech.para: That appears to outline the degree of broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings throughout the world. The House of Commons is completely opposed to the idea of such broadcasts. Mr. Attlee opposed the proposal as strongly and as firmly as did Mr. Chamberlain, and I believe that the House of Commons itself even refused to allow the war-time speeches of Mr. Churchill to be recorded and re-broadcast. Great Britain has really kept its Parliament down to the level sought by Senator Marriott, that is, completely free from outside influence, or whatever influence radio exercises on parliamentary proceedings.

Broadcasting was introduced into the Parliament on 5th July, 1946, by the Labour government of the day. It was brought in as the result of a recommendation by a joint parliamentary committee, and was a multi-party approach, all parties agreeing to its establishment. Complete control of parliamentary broadcasting was set up by statute and vested in a joint parliamentary committee. Therefore, the Parliament has kept this matter completely under its own control. Hitherto, I have been talking about the mechanics of broadcasting, but there are great principles underlying the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings. We uphold the democratic ideal that unless a minority viewpoint can be fully and adequately expressed, we lack one of the salient features of a democracy. Let me assume that in what we term a democracy one side was able to present its viewpoint fully, completely and adequately, but the other side could not present its viewpoint at all. Would anybody claim that we had a democracy under those conditions? Of course not. If one side is able to give an adequate presentation and the other a most inadequate one, we have still not achieved democracy. It is one of the fundamental elements of the democratic form of government and society which we espouse that there should be adequate opportunity for the presentation of opposing views in all political matters. That is one of the basic reasons why the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings was introduced.

There is a danger in a country like ours, where we find a powerful metropolitan press which is rapidly ousting the country press, through the new means of air transport, and becoming very powerful. The press has very vital interests in the complete medium of mass communication - radio broadcasting - and it has been accorded a dominating position in the rather limited present field of television, that new and improved means of mass communication. Therefore, the power to communicate to the people is largely in one set of hands, and itcould be that only one viewpoint would be presented in matters of fundamental principle. A correction of that, and a very desirable one, is the broadcast of parliamentary proceedings.

At least the opportunity is given to the elector to hear what goes on although very often after listening to a debate he is still in doubt about which side is right. That happens for a number of reasons the chief of which is that matters in this country are so interlocked that we cannot touch one phase of our social business activities without impinging upon and affecting many others. Accordingly, there is no all good solution of any problem that faces the country or Government. Many things can be said against every possible solution. Maybe a government selects a particular approach to a problem because there are 52 points in its favour and 48 against. When the matter comes to the Parliament, one side argues for and presents the 48 per cent. and the other side presents the 52 per cent. If the bemused elector picks the side with 48 points surely it is no wonder but he has the opportunity to hear the case from both sides; and I believe that the strength of a democracy depends upon the degree of enlightenment - political and cultural - of its citizens. On that statement I base the further statement that no government can proceed much further or faster than ordinary contemporary thought will allow it. In the end, the Government has to go back to the tempo of current thought among the people. So, if we want to progress in our policies, and if we want action, the minds of the people have to be brought to a stage where they are informed and trained in thinking on political matters. While everybody here knows perfectly well that what takes place in this chamber impinges upon the lives of our people at every point every day, at home, at work and on the streets, how few of the people have the faintest idea that what happens here has an effect on them. If they did realize it, how much more interest would they take in the deliberations of people who are shaping their lives and those of their children? We are serving the cause of democracy in an essential way in allowing these proceedings to be broadcast. Insofar as we offend people, that is our fault, not the fault of the broadcasting of the proceedings. If there are faults in our behaviour we must correct them. That matter surely lies in the hands of the parliamentarians.

On the question of the interest taken by the people in parliamentary broadcasts, I have no personal knowledge of whether a great many people listen or not, but I know that I have no anonymity on a tram ot train. That may be because I talk too much in this place when we are on the air. If I say a sentence outside the Parliament among strangers, they tell me who I am. They know my voice, because they have heard me speak over the air, and they can identify me instantly. I have had thai experience so many times that it inclines me to the opinion that many people do listen to the broadcasts of these proceedings.

There is one phenomenon which rather proves that people do listen, and that the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings has stimulated an enormous interest in the Parliament. From the time that Parliament began to be broadcast, Pioneer buses began coming to Canberra, and loads of sightseers visit Parliament almost daily. The promoters of those tours did not make a deviation from the regular route on their own initiative. They told the late Mr. Chifley and myself that they were forced to do so because travellers wanted to see the National Parliament. Their interest had been stimulated, and as a result, these bus tours never now miss Canberra. The interest of the travelling public has been stimulated by the broadcasting of Parliament. It has brought the proceedings into their homes, and aroused their interest.

It is an excellent thing that young children should know of the existence ot Parliament, and gradually acquire some understanding of the political society in which they live. I have searched the gallup polls - or had them searched for mc - to find out whether there had been any assessment of public opinion on this matte . The only one I can find was published in November, 1954, and the Senate may be interested to know what were the findings. The heading is -

quote.para: Fewer want to hear Parliament.

speech.para: No doubt that statement will please the mover of the motion. The report continues -

quote.para: A reduced, but fairly substantial, majority or the public wants parliamentary broadcasts to continue, a Gallup poll found in October. Asked, " Do you think broadcasting from Federal Parliament should be continued, reduced or stopped? " - 1,860 men and women answered -

speech.para: That means that 66 per cent, of the people wanted parliamentary broadcasts to continue.

talk.start.para: - That is 66 per cent, of the listeners.
- That is so. Eleven per cent, wanted the broadcasts continued but reduced, but a total of 66 per cent, were in favour of the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings.
- That would be 66 per cent, of the people interviewed.

- It means 66 per cent, of the exact number asked - 1,860. This was a normal kind of gallup poll, which is usually found to be reasonably accurate - as I have discovered to my discomfort politically, on occasions. The remaining results were -

speech.para: Only 15 per cent, of the people wanted them stopped, and 19 per cent, had no opinion. Those percentages varied from 1952, when 72 per cent, wanted the broadcasts to continue. In 1953, 57 per cent, wanted a continuance, and in 1954, 55 per cent. If that poll truly reflects public opinion, obviously a majority of the public is in favour of continuing the broadcasts. In those circumstances, I regret that I cannot join Senator Marriott in voting for a proposal which would mean the termination of parliamentary broadcasts. I agree with him that we can improve the mechanics of the system. It may well be that the debate which he has now provoked will lead to some further consideration of those methods, but I should be bitterly disappointed if the Senate were to carry a resolution that the proceedings of the Parliament should no longer be broadcast.

Allied with broadcasting is television, and this reminds me of a story that I heard Lord Bruce tell some years ago after Mr. Keith Ewert had unexpectedly won the seat of Flinders - a rather fickle electorate of Victoria. On the Monday after the election, the Prime Minister was speaking to a small gathering and bemoaning the fact that he had lost his man in Flinders. Lord Bruce said: " Mr. Prime Minister, you should not complain about Flinders. I am the one with the world's greatest grievance against Flinders. In 1929, when I was Prime Minister of this country, they threw me to the wolves ". At the election in that year he had been defeated by 20,000 votes. For three years he was abroad in England attending to his private business, but when he returned at the end of that period, the same fickle electorate, without one minute of campaigning by him, re-elected him with a majority of 20,000.

talk.start.para: - They realized their error.

- He based the result on a different ground. He said, " If you want the electors to love you, never let them see you ". That may be a word of warning to honorable senators about television. Lord Bruce went on to say: "Thereafter I went away and became High Commissioner in London for a period of fifteen years. I made only three trips back to Australia during that time, and each one was deliberately short. Now I find I come back somewhat in the nature of a national hero". He then said again, " If you want the electors to love you* never let them see you".
- Is that why the honorable Leader of the Opposition advocates,. " Sydney or the bush "?

- If Senator Wright cares to raise that point, I think I might remind him that quite recently I gave a rather effective demonstration of such at slogan. However, I am applying Lord Bruce's story not in the context which. Senator Wright has chosen to pick up, but in relation to television. Quite seriously, I suggest to the Senate - and I am not looking at any one in particular when I say this - that it would be much better if the proceedings of Parliament were not televised. It would stir up the vanity of honorable senators even a little more than, radio broadcasting does.
- Senators would have to get a face-lift occasionally.

- Face-lifts and colouring and all the rest. I do not decry the need for some vanity in people who grace this chamber. I think it is important. When all vanity goes, one has given up theconflict of life altogether, and should be pensioned off. It is good to have a reasonably good opinion of oneself, and one would not be concerned about his appearance if there were not just a little vanity. If any one tells us that we, in the Parliament, are vain, I plead guilty, because within bounds, vanity can be regarded as a virtue rather than as a vice.

speech.para: I have talked longer than I thought this motion would inspire me to do, but I have been interested in the matter. Senator Marriott has rendered a service in raising: it and providing an opportunity for honorable senators to express their views, but I regret that I cannot join him in the proposition that parliamentary broadcasts should cease.

talk.start.para: . - Somewhat in the same spirit as the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) I should like to speak to Senator Marriott's motion. There are aspects of it which I can support and others with which I find myself in opposition. While the Leader of the Oppositionwas dealing with the matter, I almost felt, during the early stages, that he was making: his speech from notes that I have prepared, - particularly when he spoke in regard to the mechanics of the subject. I shall attempt to break new ground. The motion contains two main provisions - that a ban should be placed on the broadcasting of proceedings in both Houses, or, alternatively that the present practice of broadcasting parliamentary proceedings shall be restricted to question time and important speeches. In the same breath, however, the honorable senator writes off the second leg of his motion. He said, " My alternative is of little value ". The Leader of the Opposition also suggests that the alternative is of little value, but I suggest that the alternative does have some value, and, during the course of my speech, I shall make reference to a fairly reliable authority in support of that contention.

speech.para: The mover of the motion postulated three main propositions and proceeded to supply an answer to them; their propositions are the burden of the motion. He asked, in effect, " Does the microphone rule the Parliament? Does the broadcasting of proceedings of the Parliament lower the prestige or reputation of the Parliament? " And, " Is the practice of broadcasting the proceedings of the Parliament distasteful to the general public or unwanted by it? " Then, in his speech, he produced an affirmative answer to those three questions and that, he said, was the basis of his motion. The three questions he postulated need closer examination. For instance, simply to say that the introduction of the budget at 8 o'clock at night instead of at 3 o'clock in the afternoon, is evidence that the microphone rules the Parliament, is, on the face of it, absurd. In addition to the reasons that were given by the Leader of the Opposition, it has been the practice for some considerable time to deliver the budget speech as late in the day as possible, and for very good reasons. It is desirable, and, in fact, essential, that there should not be trading in relation to budget matters on the day on which the budget is presented. At 8 o'clock at night, the Stock Exchange has closed and everybody has gone home from business for the day.

Another very good reason why the budget speech should be made at 8 o'clock is that since the people pay the taxes they have the right to listen to the budget speech; and, obviously, more people are enabled to listen to it at 8 o'clock, by virtue of their working hours, than at 3 o'clock in the afternoon. To suggest that the microphone is ruling the Parliament simply because the budget is presented at, 8 o'clock at night cannot be substantiated in reason. Senator Marriott then suggested that the reduction of the period allowed to each speaker from an hour to 30 minutes also was evidence of the tendency of the microphone to rule the Parliament. Whilst I admit that there is some juggling of time for speakers on the air, surely it is desirable in the interests of the electors that most important matters of national and State interest should be discussed when the greatest number of listeners are available to hear such discussions. The reduction of the time allowed to each speaker is, as the Leader of the Opposition said, all to the good as it tends to produce better rather than worse speeches. Mr. Adlai Stevenson, the selected Democratic candidate for the Presidency of the United States of America, is on record as having said that if he were asked to make a speech and he had two hours in which to do so he would speak for two hours, but if he were given a week to prepare the speech he would speak for an hour, and if he were given a fortnight to prepare it he would speak for only half an hour and make a very good speech. I think that is true. When one speaks extempore one cannot be so selective in his choice of arguments; he has not the time to weigh the pros and cons of what he is going to say. On the other hand, if he knows he is limited to half an hour he must put his head down and concentrate on the telling points which he thinks will add to the debate, and, therefore, will make a better speech. Rather than the microphone ruling the Parliament, we can say on that argument, that broadcasting is of assistance to the Parliament, because it makes for more worthwhile and penetrating speeches.

Secondly, Senator Marriott asked, in effect, " Does broadcasting lower the prestige of the Parliament? " In answer to that question I think we can say, " Yes " and " No ". There is no doubt that whilst in certain circumstances the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings would lower the prestige of the Parliament, on the other hand there are circumstances in which it improves the prestige of the Parliament. If there is a lack of dignity on the part of an honorable senator, surely the more his electors know about it the better. It seems to me that if an honorable member or honorable senator becomes famous or infamous for his conduct in the Parliament, it is all to the better that his electors should know about it. On balance, the fact of his knowing that his electors will be aware of whether he is disorderly or rude will tend to restrain him. In those circumstances, broadcasting may improve his conduct rather than cause it to be discreditable. In any case, we are a fairly robust people. We play the game hard and we debate pretty hard; we are not a race of cissies. We like to blow off and say what we think; and it is far better that we should do that than carry on as do members of the parliaments of some countries where they get down to firing at one another, have unseemly brawls and resort to lethal weapons. We express our view in the Parliament and hold to our point of view, but we have a democratic way of doing so. In that regard, I do not think that the honorable senator can sustain the point that he has raised.

In relation to Senator Marriott's third point, I may be able to get on his side. He posed the question, " Is the broadcasting of proceedings in the Parliament distasteful to the general public or unwanted by it? " We are in a position to bring forward some figures and some research upon that question. It is rather an odd thing that the Leader of the Opposition should have quoted from a Gallup poll in respect of which I have precisely the same document as that from which he quoted. The document is here for anybody to peruse.

talk.start.para: - When was it published?

- It was published in November, 1 954. This is the same document from which the honorable senator quoted. I can say that with certainty, because he read it verbatim, and I followed him through on the document before me. What the honorable senator quoted is definitely in the document but the heading is -

quote.para: Few usually listen to Parliament-

speech.para: That, of course, is directly the opposite from what he said. Then the article reads -

quote.para: In a typical week in October, only one adult in six listened to Federal Parliament for a quarter of an hour or more.
This Gallup Poll was made after Parliament had been sitting, for the usual three days, in the week to October 16.

talk.start.para: - Why, it is better than a Jack Davey session!

- So, it is suggested that fewer people now listen to the parliamentary broadcasts than formerly. There also appears in the same document a comment to the effect that the Senate has grown in favour and popularity. I am sure that all honorable senators will be pleased to hear that that is so. Although the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) cited the gallup poll as testimony that broadcasts of parliamentary proceedings are popular, I suggest that it is clear from this document that opinion blows hot and cold in this regard. Certainly the document as a whole implies that fewer people now listen to parliamentary broadcasts than formerly. That, of course, supports substantially what Senator Marriott has said.

speech.para: I should like to revert to the question of limited broadcasting, as envisaged in Senator Marriott's motion. He suggests that parts only of the parliamentary proceedings, such as question time in both Houses, and important speeches in either House, should be broadcast. I have before me several annual reports of the Australian Broadcasting Commission. The reports for 1952 and 1953 definitely advocate some modification of the broadcasting of parliamentary debates such as is envisaged in the motion. For instance, the 1952 report contains this paragraph -

quote.para: The Commission is of opinion that the institution of parliamentary broadcasts was a wise one, and that the service it performs is a highly significant contribution to the better information of the electorate of a democracy. We feel that it is a proven technique which should be continued, but are also of opinion that a revision of the total broadcasts of parliamentary sessions should now be undertaken in the light of our experience since 1946. A discrimination as between those sessions of Parliament which make good broadcasting and those which do not, is admittedly difficult, and any limitation of broadcasts from the House might well necessitate some rearrangement of House procedure. The Commission feels, however, that some such revision would be in the interests not only of the National Service but of Parliament itself, and would certainly increase the level of Parliamentary listening in the ultimate. i think that that was fair comment, and 1 should like lo hear the views of other honorable senators on it. The portion of the commission's 1953 report relating to parliamentary broadcasts contains this observation -

While public appreciation of noteworthy debates, of important Ministerial statements and of Question Time has remained satisfactory, the general level of listening has deteriorated markedly in recent years . . . The Commission feels obliged to express the opinion that the future good estate of Parliamentary broadcasting is dependent upon some limitation of these sessions. In accordance with this conviction, we have therefore suggested, for the consideration of Parliament, that the broadcasts would be more effective if the repetitive paris of debates, the committee stages and some of the purely formal business were eliminated The Commission is convinced that the important purposes for which Parliamentary broadcasts were introduced, and indeed the prestige of Parliament itself, would be immensely furthered by the adoption of some such policy.

speech.para: That, surely, is a clear indication that the Australian Broadcasting Commission which, after all, handles parliamentary broadcasts, considers that there should be some revision and, to that degree, supports a part of Senator Marriott's motion. It is interesting to observe that the commission directed attention also to the repetitive part of parliamentary proceedings. I have made inquiries in relation to divisions. 1 find that a division takes about six and a half minutes in the House of Representatives. The records show that between noon on the 9th April, 1935, and 12.45 a.m. on the following day, there were no less than 83 divisions during the passage of a supply bill. One can imagine the reactions of persons listening to the broadcast of such proceedings. They would hear, over and over again, the direction from the Chair, " The ayes will pass to the right of the chair, and the noes to the left. The question is so-and-so." This would be accompanied by the buzz of 120 members conversing while the tellers counted the divisions.

Coming to more recent times, during the passage of the Australian Stevedoring Industry Bill earlier this year, after 8 o'clock one evening there were 30 divisions. At an average of six and a half minutes for each division, the time occupied in divisions alone was about 195 minutes, or approximately three and a quarter hours. So, all that the listening public heard on that evening was a series of useless divisions.

That occurred during the last sessional period of the Parliament. On that occasion, trie broadcast of the proceedings was reduced lo an absurdity. We say that we believe in the freedom of the individual to choose his entertainment. In all seriousness, I ask honorable senators whether they would prefer to listen to one division after another, or to a symphony concert? Why should a member of the public who has paid his licence-fee and who, perhaps, has worked hard all day and is seeking relaxation and entertainment in the evening, have to listen to endless divisions extending over a period of three and a quarter hours? 1 remind honorable senators that many radio listeners can get satisfactory reception of only one national station and that may be the one which broadcasts parliamentary proceedings. 1 believe that we should look at this matter sensibly and consider whether there should not be a modification of the practice of broadcasting parliamentary proceedings.

talk.start.para: - We could easily alter it.

- If this debate leads to a modification of the present practice, I think it will have been completely justified. 1 am sure that nobody in his sound senses would support the continuance of a practice under which the people have to listen to parliamentary broadcasts-
- They do not have to listen to them.

- I think that people living in certain districts where satisfactory broadcast reception is obtained from only a national station which broadcasts parliamentary proceedings are perhaps entitled to more consideration than city dwellers who can exercise a wide choice of radio stations.

speech.para: To show that the instances that I have given of endless divisions taking place were not isolated occasions, I point out that after 8 p.m. on one night in 1951, there were 28. Obviously, therefore, there is a good case for some modification of the present practice. The Leader of the Opposition referred to the practice in other parts of the world. I do not think that the members of the Mother of Parliaments, the House of Commons, are denied an opportunity to express adequately democratic ideals because the proceedings of that British Parliament are not broadcast. The proceedings of the

American Congress are not broadcast, while in New Zealand, only question time and selected parts of the proceedings are broadcast. I think he was stretching it a little too far when he implied that it was introduced because one particular party or group of parties was seeking to obtain a monopoly over others. That suggestion is quickly answered by the fact that the mother of all parliaments, the great House of Commons in England, does not choose to use this medium of disseminating propaganda. Proceedings are not broadcast from Congress or the Senate in America, and I do not think it can be suggested that in those two great countries the points of view of all parties are not expressed adequately.

So, I come to the point at which I cannot support the suggestion that we should cease broadcasting the proceedings of this Parliament. In my view, the broadcasting of question time in Parliament is most interesting and informative. As a layman, it was most absorbing to me. I know from the people among whom I move from time to time that the listening audience is tremendous. Again, I believe it is right that we should broadcast speeches by our leaders on matters of great moment to the nation. They are of paramount importance and interest to a great listening audience, but, at the same time, nobody will ever convince me that the listening public wants to continue listening to broadcasts of the discussion of a bill which has been before both Houses of the Parliament for days, perhaps even for weeks, and which has reached the stage at which nothing new can be said upon it. Again, I shall never be convinced that the public is anxious to listen at a time when we have nothing but division after division, perhaps for hours.

Senator Marriott's suggestion is well worth considering. His motion has focused our attention on a serious problem. We have now a broadcasting committee of which Senator Marriott is a member. It is an all-party committee. Its members have been drawn from all parties of the two Houses and I suggest that this committee should go to work, that it should call evidence if necessary and that it should examine the suggestions made to it from time to time by the Australian Broadcasting Commission in its reports. If this were done I am confident that in the long run we should see introduced some modification of the present system, a modification which would take nothing from the great listening audience but which, on the contrary, would give the Australian people a better overall idea of what the Parliament is doing. It may be in some tabloid or concentrated form; certainly it should be in a form that can be readily understood by the people. After all, radio was .intended primarily as a form of entertainment. I know that one man's meat is another man's poison. Some people like chamber music, yet, at the present time, on Saturday afternoons all one can hear over the radio is some fellow talking about horses. We have to take that, whether we like it or not.

talk.start.para: - Some people even like cricket.

- Some people even like listening to broadcasts of cricket matches. We must provide a good cross section of entertainment for the public, and if the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings is handled properly more people will take an interest in them. That part of the radio programme should become educational and informative. It could stimulate interest in our National Parliament; but if we allow things to continue as they are, we shall kill interest in our National Parliament. Here we have an excellent opportunity to readjust our broadcasting system and make it something that will be good for the Parliament and the nation.

.-- At the outset, I commend Senator Marriott for bringing forward this matter. . It gives us a splendid opportunity to discuss an important subject, although I disagree with his suggestion that it should be discussed only by the Senate. I see no reason why it should not be discussed by the House of Representatives also. 1 do not know what he had in mind in suggesting that discussion be confined to this chamber.

speech.para: Senator Marriott also suggested that he had looked at speeches delivered ten years ago, that he has listened to broadcasts and that he finds that ten years ago the questions being asked were similar to those asked to-day. If he is alive in twenty years' time no doubt he will notice that what appear to be similar questions will be asked then.

Might 1 remind him that times change, that personalities and circumstances change and that although the questions might appear to be similar, generally speaking they will actually become vastly different individually. Senator Marriott then said that the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings was harmful and wasteful. He said that people did not want it. I have spoken to many about the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings. When I was President of the Senate, the then Prime Minister of New Zealand told me that if the people of New Zealand were given a vote on whether parliamentary proceedings should be broadcast, they would vote overwhelmingly in favour of it. Many people agree that we should have certain rights and privileges. They might not listen even though they agree that proceedings should be broadcast. They might turn off their radios when certain senators speak. On one occasion, Senator Foll, as he then was, told me that he hated speaking over the air because immediately he rose to speak his vivid imagination made him almost hear thousands of clicks as people began switching off their radios. I said to him that it was no wonder if they switched off because, having been forced, as President, to sit in the chair and listen to him, I could well understand their doing so. No doubt, Mr. Deputy President, there have been many times, when certain senators were speaking, when you would have liked to turn off the debate and have a quiet nap.

It is absurd to say that Parliament is ruled by the microphone. As the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna) has pointed out, there are many members of the Parliament who think that they are great orators, and who imagine that people are waiting with bated breath to hear them speak; but I agree that there is nothing wrong with broadcasting speeches on important matters. We have many debates on matters of urgent interest to the public and it is essential that they be broadcast for the benefit and information of our people. They should be allowed to listen to debates on the air. I believe that argument was rather weak.

I was amazed to hear Senator Marriott suggest that if we were to turn off the microphones and no longer permit the broadcasting of speeches by members of Parliament, the newspapers of Australia would publish reports of our speeches. Senator Marriott is an optimist. If there were no broadcasting whatever, we would not get one extra line in the press. There was a time when all the speeches were printed. In South Australia and Tasmania, the newspaper reporters took a full account of the speeches, and their reports were published in the form of " Hansard ".

I do not believe that the newspaper proprietors would bother about our speeches because they have to appeal to the people so that they can sell their newspapers. The people want something different and exciting. Newspaper work has degenerated in a large measure simply because journalists have educated the mass of the people to expect exciting news. If they do not get it, circulation falls. I do not blame the newspaper proprietors. If we were running a newspaper, we would expect to make it pay, and the people must get what they are seeking.

Senator Marriott referred to what he termed " mythical listeners ". I say that there are thousands of listeners, at various times, throughout Australia. I have met many people, and have been astonished when they asked me questions about certain matters that had arisen in this chamber. Sometimes they happened when I was not in the chamber, and I have had to talk myself out of trouble. Fortunately, I have a facility in that direction, and that is an asset for a politician. I almost agreed with Senator Marriott on another point that he raised. If there had been a division at the time, I might have been on his side. I thought he was on the right lines when he said there should be some investigation into the alteration of broadcasting times, and the bringing forward of certain speeches.

talk.start.para: - Will the honorable senator sing a song during divisions?

-I want to make my speech as interesting as I can. I will not sing to Senator Henty, but perhaps I shall tell a story or two. Some time ago, I read the autobiography of Lord Snowden. I heard him speak on many occasions years ago when the world was wide and the heart was young. Lord Snowden said that the whole Parliament should not sit as a committee. Of course, he was speaking of the United Kingdom Parliament, which had a membership exceeding 600. He said it was foolish to expect 600 people sitting in parliament, especially in committee, to conduct the business of the nation. When we are discussing the second reading of a measure, we are dealing with general principles as applied to the bill, but when we are in committee we discuss details, and they can be very boring.

speech.para: I remember that " Punch " once recorded that the Duke of Devonshire had spoken at some length. When he had finished, a lady in his audience said to him, " My dear Duke, while you were speaking you were asleep ". The Duke replied, " Oh, no! I. was not asleep. I wish I had been; my speech was so boring." Speeches made in committee are boring because they deal with details. I would favour a change in the broadcasting arrangements to omit the committee stages, but I would be utterly and bitterly opposed to any attempt to stop the people from hearing second-reading debates, which are of great importance to the nation.

Senator Marriott said that the proceedings sometimes gave the impression of a donnybrook. Some listeners are delighted to listen to proceedings in the House of Representatives. One woman told me a few weeks ago that the Senate was too sedate, but she liked to listen to the House of Representatives. To that extent, I suppose that honorable members in another place are serving a useful purpose if they can be entertaining to somebody. We should not abolish broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings simply because of a rustling of papers or the impression that a donnybrook is in progress. That is a matter for the Australian Broadcasting Commission.Probably the trouble could be rectified it the technicians set to work on it. As it is, I believe they have improved the broadcasting reception compared with the earlier days.

Senator Marriott said that there was tedious repetition. Bills were discussed by the House of Representatives, and then debated in the Senate where similar arguments were adduced. 1 agree with him completely, but instead of abolishing broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings, we should abolish the Senate. Of course, that would not find any favour with my present listeners.

talk.start.para: - Would Senator Brown vote for the abolition of the Senate?

- Certainly I would not. When I first entered this Parliament, I spoke at Rockhampton, and at the close of the meeting a man asked, " Senator Brown, do you support the abolition of the Senate? " I replied, " Certainly I do. but please do not abolish it just now; 1 have only just been elected ". Although I believe in supporting my party's platform, which provides for the abolition of the Senate, 1 know the people would not agree to it so it is useless to talk about it.
- You are not going to try to do it gently?

- I am not going to try at all. I am a realist. I have been here 25 years, and I know I will not be here another 25 years whether the Senate is abolished or not. At this late hour, 1 am not going around the country trying to convince the people that the Senate has deteriorated and is no longer of any service. A senator who was a very rich man was discussing the Senate with me once in a rather derogatory way. He was of the opinion that perhaps it .should be abolished. 1 told him that I would agree with him provided that after it was abolished our salaries were paid to us, as displaced senators, for the rest of our lives. That was twenty years ago.

speech.para: There is a constant struggle among senators and members of the House of Representatives to get on the air, and 1 do not blame them for that. I have been a senator for about 25 years. Indeed, I am the father of the .Senate, but I do not get any medals for that. In my long and interesting career in the Senate, for which I am most grateful to the people of Queensland, who sent me here, I have seen honorable senators become quite excited with each other and fight bitterly over measures that have been presented to us. I have been as bad as the rest in that respect; and our words have been embalmed in " Hansard " but have been read by very few. After all those speeches and struggles, what has been accomplished? In my 25 years here, not one bill has been amended very seriously, and we might as well have passed the measures put before us at the beginning without speaking and struggling about them. But with the introduction of broadcasting that has changed. When honorable senators rise now they know that they are not simply trying to convince the members of the Government or of the Opposition, whichever it may be, but are also speaking to thousands of good Australians.

All politicians are exhibitionists to some extent, and much pleasure is given to those who are speaking from this chamber when they know that their words are being broadcast to many thousands of their countrymen. When I was President of the Senate, Mr. Speaker Rosevear and myself often received complaints from members of the Parliament that they were not given enough broadcasting time. Mr. Rosevear and myself discussed this matter and we decided to get the officers of the Parliament to look up the records and find out just how long each honorable senator and honorable member had spoken while the proceedings were being broadcast. We discovered that the three gentlemen who had complained most bitterly were among the five who had been given most time on the air.

Of course, men are only human, and they like to receive as much broadcasting time as possible. I believe that it is only right that a representative, or senator, from Western Australia, for example, should be given broadcasting time when it best suits the people of that State to listen to him, that is round about 10 o'clock at night here. I have no objection to that, and when I have been asked to relinquish my right lo speak so that a Western Australian could use the time, I have cheerfully agreed to do so. I have done that because I think of my party, and because of the benefits that will accrue to the benighted Western Australians. A duty devolves upon every member of both Houses of the Parliament to try to speak in such a way that he will interest and inform those listening to him over the radio. I am not averse to a man using his ability as an entertainer to tell a story if it applies to a matter under discussion.

Not long ago I was due to speak while the proceedings here were being broadcast, but as I did not feel like speaking at that time I told the Whip that I did not intend to accept my opportunity. That reminds me that about that time I was having a conversation with a " Hansard " reporter, and I told him a story that I had heard from Sir Arthur Fadden who, as honorable senators know, is one of our best raconteurs. The matter before the Senate at that time was television, and I was speaking of my experiences in England last year where I spent, many hours watching television. I agreed with Sir Arthur Fadden that the television pictures were very lifelike. To indicate how lifelike they were, Sir Arthur Fadden told me that there was once a Yorkshireman named Jerry Higginbotham, who was working on the wharfs. He had a nice wife and a nice home, but a cissy sort of fellow began to hang around his wife. He finally told his wife not to allow him to come near the place any more.
