One day Jerry came home , early from his work on the wharfs, and it so happened that the cissy was there when he got home, but jumped behind the television set to hide. Jerry went in and sat down to watch a football match on television. It was a soccer match between Wolverhampton and Spartak. He watched it intently for a while, and after about, twenty minutes of crouching down behind the television cabinet the cissy got cramps, jumped up and ran out. Jerry looked up startled and said, " That's funny, I never saw that man do anything illegal. What did the referee send him off for? " Any one who' has seen television will realize that that story illustrates how realistic the pictures are; and if television is introduced to this Parliament it will be just as realistic.

However, we can be too realistic, like the alderman who was opposed to girls wearing bikini costumes on the seafront. He was not opposed to them for the same reason as the wowsers, but because he thought the girls looked better in less revealing costumes. That lends point to my belief that while broadcasting of parliamentary procedures is a benefit, the televising of parliamentary proceedings would show too much. I would like honorable senators and members of the House of Representatives to endeavour to make the broadcasting of our proceedings more inviting to those who love to listen to the debates. While I was President of the Senate I suggested to Mr. Chifley that it would be a good thing if we could record the voices of senators and members and play them back to the speakers so that they could listen to themselves, recognize their faults and attempt to correct their diction, grammar and so on. We obtained a wire recorder and placed it on the Senate side, and with the assistance of Mr. Edwards and Mr. Loof we had it wired up. Before that was done, the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Committee had met, and I had informed its members of what I intended to do. They said to me, " If you do that you will find yourself up against this committee". I said "Why?" They replied, " Because you are contravening the act. You must not re-broadcast ". I said, " Good heavens! I am not going to rebroadcast. I am only going to take down what senators say, so that they can hear themselves". I was stopped from doing so and I was rather angry, and I threatened that I would make a record irrespective of the committee's ruling. However, when I cooled down I realized that that would be a foolish thing to do.

For three months, the pros and cons of this matter were considered by the Solicitor-General, and after much cogitating on his part I received a letter to say, " Mr. President, this matter has been settled. You can place a tape or wire recorder in your chambers ". I did so, and the result was remarkable. 1 think Senator Aylett was one of the first to record on it and listen to himself. He then sought to improve himself, and next time he spoke in Hobart the community said that it was the best address over the air they had heard from him. That was all because he recorded his speech on the wire recorder, and after hearing himself took action to improve his method of speaking. About two years ago, I read an account in the " Sydney Morning Herald " of a parson in England who heard a record of one of his sermons on a tape recorder. He said, " Good heavens, have I been talking to my parishioners for 30 years like that?" They said, "That's you ". He said, " I take my oath, here and now, that I will not impose on my parishioners again until I have improved myself" He kept out of the pulpit for twelve months, and when he went back his congregation hardly recognized his preaching because he had become such a splendid speaker.

One of our own senators, a most popular member of the Government, heard, himself on tape and received a great surprise. I said to him, " Senator, the boys on our side think you are very human". He said, " Why? Why am I very human? " I said, "To 'er' is human". He said, 'I don't er ', I cut that out years ago ". I said, " Brother, come and listen to yourself in my chambers ". He came in and listened to one of his speeches that 1 had recorded, and he exclaimed, " Good God! Is that me? " I said, " Yes, that's you all right ". Next day when he was speaking - he was in Opposition then - instead of " er-ing " he paused. When that great evangelist, Evan Evans, who was a great orator, first started in South Wales to convert the people to Christianity - or to his idea of Christianity - he asked a prominent divine, who had listened to him one night, "What did you think of my speech? " The prominent divine replied, " Cultivate the pause ". This senator cultivated the pause, and he improved out of sight.

I will not bore the Senate any longer. Senator Anderson made a splendid point in regard to divisions. How conservative we are in this Parliament, both Labour and Liberal. We have adopted a certain course of action, and we do not like to move away from it. We go on, year in and year out, in the same way and bore the listeners intolerably. Senator Anderson made a good suggestion as to what, should happen in parliamentary broadcasts while divisions are being taken. I remind honorable senators who are cricket lovers of what happens in that benighted country overseas where it rains nearly all the year round. It was remarkable, however, that during my visit to England, in four months the skies were clouded on only about seven days. Because of the rain cricket test matches are often interrupted, but the British Broadcasting Corporation has dealt with the situation in an admirable fashion. Although that commission is often criticized it is very advanced, and I express my appreciation of it. When rain stops play it brings some of the test cricketers to the microphone, and they talk about cricket. One of the experts on cricket is Johnny Moyes, who is a brother of Bishop Moyes, and during one of these rainy intervals I heard him broadcast many stories about cricket. I cannot say that I am a cricket lover, but, when I was in England, I was interested to watch the test matches on television. It is a delight to listen to Johnny Moyes discussing cricket and relating interesting anecdotes. He and his colleagues are intelligent and entertaining.

Surely in this chamber and in the House of Representatives some means could be devised to relieve the boredom of listeners during the recording of divisions. What is to prevent an expert on parliamentary procedure or parliamentary history relating a few good stories, or explaining to the listening public some of the things that happen in Parliament, such as the procedure of passing a bill. I should be in favour of that being done. Some of the stories of the late Joe Gander, one of the finest humorists in Parliament, and also of that veteran, the late Sir George Reid, could be recounted with great interest and entertainment. Stories of political activities in this House would also appeal to the listeners. I recall one occasion in the House of Representatives when our late departed friend, the Honorable Archie Cameron, was speaking as a private member. He was a great gentleman, and 1 admired him, and we all appreciated his strength of character and his personality. 1 always enjoyed his company. He was talking on country matters and dealt with potatoes, sorghum and wheat, and then he said quietly, " Now I come to onions ". Speaker Rosevear interjected, "And you will supply the tripe, also ".

Some years ago, I made two broadcasts over the Australian national radio stations and two over a Queensland commercial broadcasting station. I was subsequently asked to prepare a number of broadcast talks on humour in Parliament and the history of Parliament. As a result I spent many hours delving into old " Hansard " reports and reading many books on Parliament. I gathered together many stories, but before I was able to broadcast them the war broke out, and I became tired of my research. In addition, the man who was to employ me to give the talks died. However, I collected many stories- which I could broadcast to the people of Australia dealing with political activities and incidents in Parliament, which would interest and entertain the listening public while divisions were being taken. Perhaps the only trouble might be that the public would say, " For goodness' sake, cut out the broadcast of these speeches and let us listen to Gordon Brown ".

talk.start.para: . - Senator Marriott is to be commended' for raising the question of whether parliamentary debates should be broadcast, because it gives honorable senators an opportunity to express their views and to give some of the impressions they have gained on this subject in the course of their duties in city and country areas. I emphatically favour the complete abolition of all parliamentary broadcasts.
- What about " Hansard "?

- I cannot support the proposal to broadcast only portions of proceedings such as questions and main speeches. Questions should be asked as a means for elucidating useful information from a Minister, but since the introduction of broadcasting my impression is that very subtle propaganda has been engendered into questions which are now asked more for propaganda purposes, showmanship, or whatever else one wishes to call it, than for the purpose of obtaining real information.

speech.para: If it is decided to broadcast only certain speeches, who is to decide which ones should be broadcast? Who is to decide whether a speech will be important, because even this wise Senate cannot yet read people's minds? That is why I advocate the complete abolition of the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings. I base my opinion on the fact that it was my privilege to see this chamber in operation before broadcasting was introduced. I say emphatically that the tone and tenor of debating were on a much higher plane then than they are now when certain sittings are broadcast. I have also ascertained the opinion of people who have seen the chamber functioning since proceedings were broadcast; I am sorry that they did not see it before. I repeat that in my humble opinion broadcasting has not raised the level of debates by any means; in fact I think debates have deteriorated. As I proceed I hope I can give a few facts to support that contention.

When broadcasting was introduced its advocates said that as a result the public would be better informed on political matters. I ask honorable senators whether they honestly believe that the public is better informed on political matters to-day than it was twenty years ago?

talk.start.para: - I think so.

- 1 would be happy to agree with the honorable senator, but I do not think broadcasting has improved the public's general knowledge of parliamentary procedure. How often does one find people who do not know whether one is a member of the Senate or a member of the House of Representatives?
- Or a member of a State House.

- Or a member of a State House, or whether we have two Houses of Parliament at Canberra. When broadcasting was introduced it was a novelty. Whilst I admit that it is very difficult to assess the number of people who listen to parliamentary broadcasts, yet it is believed - this is where I differ from many other speakers - on the best available information that only 8 per cent, of the listening public listen to parliamentary broadcasts. Indeed, I venture to say that that is an over-estimate.
- One per cent.
- Senator Wood says 1 per cent.

- I am not doubting what Senator Wood says, but I am speaking for myself. I am relying on information I have gained from what I think is a relatively good source. It is one of our privileges to have our own ideas, and if any honorable senator can bowl up a curly one and say that I am incorrect I think I can make a courteous reply to justify the claim of 8 per cent.
- The honorable senator has to argue it out with Senator Wood; I am only telling him what Senator Wood thinks.

- Senator Wood and I disagree on some things, but we disagree with good grace. To-day, the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings is not a novelty, and I suggest that perhaps even now the figure might be closer to that quoted by Senator Wood. I am not suggesting that that is so. All I am saying is that the figure of 8 per cent, was given some years ago, but, perhaps, Senator Wood's figure may be nearer the mark. However, I know that the number of listeners to parliamentary broadcasts has decreased over the last five years. Whether it be 8 per cent, or otherwise let us briefly consider the outlook of those who listen to parliamentary debates. Whatever brand of politics they may support they are men who are keenly interested in politics. The question we have to ask ourselves is: Are they any better informed on politics to-day through the medium of broadcasts? I very much doubt it. Remarks that have been made this evening bear out my assessment that perhaps the only thing they have gained is the ability to distinguish between showmanship in politics that is exhibited over the air and the plain down-to-earth political debates. I am more than ever fortified in that opinion by what has transpired in this debate this evening as the result of the contributions by the Leader of the Opposition (Senator McKenna), Senator Brown and others. They have all agreed that there is jockeying for position - collusion if one likes to call it - and that debates are arranged to give to the public not a true but a false idea of debates in the Parliament.

speech.para: Prior to the introduction of broadcasting the public of Australia were dependent on the press to report faithfully the debates of Parliament. In addition " Hansard " was readily available. I believe that those were two excellent, valuable media for public information. Even if broadcasting were abolished, and I favour its abolition, the loss of information to the public of Australia would be very small indeed because the people who now listen would either read reports in the press or, better still, they would read " Hansard ". If broadcasting were abolished there would be a very desirable reduction of sensationalism and showmanship.

I repeat that the broadcasting of parliamentary debates has not enhanced the reputation of the Parliament. When we consider some of the arrangements that are made for parliamentary broadcasting, what do we find? We find that the time a man or woman may speak when the proceedings are being broadcast has been mutually limited to 30 minutes. For many well-informed speakers, to whom I listen with a great deal of pleasure in this chamber, 30 minutes is not sufficient time to enable them to deal with subjects under discussion. The result is that when a speaker is unable, in the allotted time, to bring out certain points, a political opponent who follows him will seize upon those points and criticize him, most unfairly, for his failure to deal with them. The senator so criticized has no redress.

As 1 said earlier, the standard of debate in this chamber' is much higher when our proceedings are not being broadcast than when we are on the air. I was pleased to hear Senator Brown refer to what occurs in committee. In my humble opinion, it is at that stage that the down-to-earth business of politics is carried on. It is then that considerable cut and thrust takes place in debate, and senators have an opportunity to bring out every point, even getting' down to particular lines or words of a bill. The Minister in charge of the measure has an opportunity to reply fully. Although, as Senator Brown and other honorable senators have said, this is the very essence of the parliamentary system, it is not popular with the listening public. Because the very kernel of parliamentary debate - the strongest feature of our parliamentary system - does not make a popular appeal, it is very rarely broadcast.

It is very hard to gauge whether or not the listening public favours broadcasts of parliamentary proceedings, and 1 doubt whether any member of the Parliament receives much mail for or against a continuance of the practice. I certainly know that the mail received by the presiding officer on this subject is not voluminous. The bulk of the correspondence received by the presiding officers and by senators and members emanates from a hard core Of political enthusiasts. Therefore, it cannot be accepted as giving an accurate idea of the reactions of the general public to parliamentary broadcasts.

I come now to an important aspect of this matter, namely, the wishes of the general public. Much of the correspondence that honorable senators receive confirms the belief that many people object to parliamentary broadcasts because they seriously interfere with advertised programmes. At a conservative estimate, I should say that 92 per cent, of the listening public who object to parliamentary broadcasts do so because of the interruption that they cause to programmes. We receive many complaints as a result of the cancellation of advertised programmes due to the uncertain sittings of the Parliament. As we all know, when the Parliament is in session not even a tentative time-table is arranged, nor is a specified period of time usually allowed for the consideration of bills. Even if the Government has in mind a likely date for the end of a sessional period, that information is successfully withheld from private members.

The Australian Broadcasting Commission must arrange its programmes months ahead. In both New South Wales and Queensland, where the " A.B.C. Weekly" is published, it is necessary for the copy to go to press many weeks ahead. In these circumstances, is it any wonder that the commission receives hundreds of complaints about inaccuracies in that publication when programmes have to be altered to suit the wishes or whims of the Parliament. I shall relate one or two instances in which that has occurred. As honorable senators will recall, it was generally believed in Canberra that the last sessional period of the Parliament would terminate at the end of May. The commission apparently shared this " inside " information, and arranged to broadcast on 19th June, an orchestral concert in which one of the leading pianists of the world was to be featured. However, as the Parliament was still in session the broadcast had to be hurriedly cancelled. In consequence, complaints poured in to the commission from every part of Australia.

talk.start.para: - Could the concert not have been broadcast by another station?

- I shall come to that aspect of the matter in a moment. The commission had also arranged for a concerto and vocal concert to be broadcast from Western Australia on 21st June. That broadcast, also, had to be cancelled because the Parliament was still sitting, and the Australian Broadcasting Commission was deluged with telegrams from the general public complaining about the cancellation of programmes that it was justly entitled to hear. Of course, the number of complaints received is always in direct ratio to the popularity of the programme that has to be cancelled.

speech.para: We have been told this evening, that, in 1953, listeners to parliamentary broadcasts were more numerous than they are to-day. In that year, the proposed broadcast of an opera was cancelled because the Parliament was still sitting. Letters flowed in to the commission from all over Australia asking why the broadcast had to be cancelled. Such complaints are just as frequent to-day as in 1953.

Due to the uncertain sittings of the Parliament, the Australian Broadcasting Commission cannot arrange for regular sessions on certain stations on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, Thursdays and sometimes on Fridays. I point out that radio audiences are built on the regularity of programme sessions. A minute or two ago Senator O'Byrne asked why a concert broadcast which had to be cancelled because of the parliamentary sittings could not have been handled by another station. At first sight, that would be an excellent idea but immediately a programme is transferred to another station a chain reaction sets in because the other programme has to be altered, and so the difficulties snowball. However, irrespective of our individual opinions as to whether or not the parliamentary proceedings should be broadcast, I am sure we all agree that the Australian Broadcasting Commission has done an excellent job in broadcasting orchestral programmes, lt has built up Australian orchestras, lt has brought to Australia the world's greatest conductors and artists. It has made a tremendous contribution to our cultural life. Mr. President, I ask for leave to continue my remarks at a later date.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

debateinfo.title: DEATH OF MR. DOUGLAS MAXWELL MOFFAT.

talk.start.para: - I. have received from the First Secretary of the American Embassy a letter of thanks for the resolution of sympathy passed by the Senate on the occasion of the death of His Excellency the Ambassador for the United States of America.

quote.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: .- 1 should like to. take this opportunity to express my sincere thanks to honorable senators on both sides of the chamber for granting me leave of absence during my recent illness. It was the first sick leave I had had in eighteen years of service in the Senate and I thank honorable senators very much indeed for it. I also thank them for the kind messages I received from them. I should like especially to thank Senator Wardlaw, who visited me several times in hospital during my illness.

speech.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.2 p.m.
